item.title: The loan system was not designed for clubs like Chelsea to sign Gonzalo Higuain... what goes on now is a cynical gaming of the system which is downright immoral
item.description: JEFF POWELL: Before the window slammed shut on transfer deadline day the light had shone through it once more onto the iniquity of Premier League clubs exploiting the loan system.
item.content:encoded:
Before the window slammed shut on transfer deadline day the light had shone through it once more onto the iniquity of Premier League clubs exploiting the loan system.

When this mechanism was first unlocked it was not designed for the likes of Chelsea begging Juventus to let Argentine World Cup striker Gonzalo Higuain pop over to London for a while or Arsenal borrowing Spanish prodigy Denis Suarez while he awaits a regular place in the Barcelona midfield.

No, the idea was for promising youngsters at the big clubs to be farmed out for first-team experience while giving a helping hand to teams lower down the divisions.

That equation was good for all parties concerned and healthy for the game.

What goes on now is a cynical gaming of the system which, while not illegal, is downright immoral.

The blame is shared with football's administrators.

The Premier League should never have sanctioned loans between their member clubs in the first place.

UEFA ought not to have followed on by approving the short-term leasing out of players between clubs in the top tier of the European leagues - such as Higuain and Suarez to the Premier League from Serie A and La Liga respectively.

That goes also for Newcastle borrowing left back Antonio Barreca from Monaco.

Such moves were not even imagined when the system was formalised in England in the World Cup year of 1966. Loans were not permitted between clubs in the same division.

By 2003 money was talking ever louder and that restriction was lifted.

That ushered in the frenzy of loan deals which lawyers have described as 'like the Wild West' in its lack of governance but really is more like a meat market.

The big names like Higuain are merely the tip of that food chain.

Chelsea have some 40 players out on loan around Britain and Europe. That is an astonishing number but they are not alone among the Premier League giants in stockpiling youngsters they may or may not have need of in the future by letting other clubs pay their wages in the meantime.

But many of those prospects, their hearts broken and futures crushed, are never heard of again.

FIFA have begun acting at last to slow this cattle train. By the start of the 2020-21 season they plan to limit - to six or eight - the number of players any club can have out on loan at one time.

But there is still no sign of a prohibition on players being loaned within the Premier League or to clubs of equal stature abroad.

And that is where football's level playing field is being trampled underfoot in the dubious cause of commercial convenience. It can tip the competitive balance in favour of a borrowing club, especially at this vital stage of the season.

Such a restriction would make clubs accountable for the players they sign, most importantly the youngsters.

As it is they can disguise their poor judgement of much of the horse-flesh they wantonly recruit by getting them off the wage bill.

We wait to see what will become of Suarez and Barreca.

But already Higuain's arrival has coincided with Chelsea's 4-0 loss at Bournemouth - their heaviest league defeat for more than 20 years - and his substitution with what seems to be recurrent back pain.

Poetic justice perhaps for his long-time admirer, manager Maurizio Sarri, especially if he finds himself leaving Chelsea before Higuain.

But the bigger question is the one which begs football to regulate against its own plague of loan sharks.

And to do so before the next window creaks open.

item.title: If Sarri-ball needs time, he's at the wrong club... time is the one luxury Chelsea managers never get
item.description: MARTIN SAMUEL - CHIEF SPORTS WRITER: If Chelsea's players lack motivation, it is the motivation to believe in what Maurizio Sarri commands. So it's them, but it's him as well.
item.content:encoded:
It is not about motivation, it is the system. If the system functions, no elite club loses 4-0 to Bournemouth.

If Chelsea's players lack motivation, it is the motivation to believe in what Maurizio Sarri commands. So it's them, but it's very much him as well. It is his grand plan that has been rumbled — and in record time, too.

It took English football years to combat what Dave Bassett was attempting at Wimbledon, but Sarri-ball in its first inception was as good as over three months in, on November 24, 2018, when Mauricio Pochettino detailed Dele Alli to shut off Chelsea's supply line through Jorginho and the system fell apart.

That is what Aaron Ramsey did for Arsenal on the day Chelsea looked so toothless in defeat at the Emirates. On Wednesday night, it was the job Eddie Howe gave to David Brooks, a 21-year-old Welsh international, late of Sheffield United.

Brooks is a fine prospect but any system that can be so spectacularly negated by a forward with 21 starts in the Premier League and a team of players, none of whom could be imagined in a Chelsea shirt, isn't as smart as it thinks it is or as smart as a lot of people think it is.

For there is very heavy investment in Sarri-ball working, mainly by the type of football analysts that Graeme Souness scornfully dismisses as bluffers: those who believe statistical sheets ahead of what they see with their own eyes, that think football has been reinvented by a handful of modern coaches and no one previously split the centre halves or the strikers, or played out from the back.

Malcolm Allison was coaching goalkeepers to kick the ball properly and pass, better to start a quick counter-attack, 50 years ago. There is very little that is new under the sun.

It comes as a surprise to the bluffers when Luka Modric stands up having won the Ballon D'Or and thanks, not Zinedine Zidane or some obscure European coach with a cult philosophy and a spread of disciples, but Harry Redknapp for changing his position and his game.

Equally, while Pochettino undoubtedly showed the way, it was Howe, an English coach quietly working a minor miracle on the south coast, who took Chelsea apart with inferior players.

Yet you won't have to look far on Friday morning for a well-constructed treatise on how the critics are wrong about Sarri-ball, how much time it takes to work and how Jorginho is actually having a wonderful season, despite increasing evidence to the contrary.

Most midfield possession won, most successful passes of any player in Europe apparently and no one is suggesting Jorginho is a failure, more that he is just not good enough in his first season to carry an entire strategy in a league far stronger, faster and more physically demanding than Serie A.

Roy Hodgson has reached 71 as a top-level manager, so one imagines is in rude health. If you want to test his blood pressure, however, start tossing out statistics without context. He can get quite prickly, Roy, if he hears about percentage possession without a mention of where it occurs on the pitch and that's what Jorginho's numbers often lack: context.

His passes total 2,136 in 23 Premier League matches, at an average of 92.8 per game. Yet the way Chelsea operate, the play invariably goes through him. Jorginho keeps them ticking over, changing angles, changing approach lines, always available, drawing players towards him.

He makes the most passes of any player in Europe for that reason so, naturally, he makes more forward passes, too. Does that by definition make him attack-minded, though? Not necessarily.

Jorginho has made 530 forward passes this season, which initially seems impressive, but that's only a quarter of his output. He hits almost as many passes backwards (270) and astray (209) and more than half his total passes (1,127), travel sideways, as anyone who watches Chelsea will testify.

How many Jorginho passes have created chances this season? Just 15 — making him the 460th most potent player in the major European leagues. With how many assists? None.

The counter-argument is that Jorginho is not there to play that final, killer pass, but to light the fire, to keep the Sarri-ball bouncing. Yet what of Chelsea when this doesn't happen? What is the strategy when Jorginho is removed from the game by a manager such as Howe, who might not have a philosophy named after him, but seems to know his football just the same?

Is Sarri a genius or a myth? If he is such a great coach, why can't he keep David Luiz's head in the game, why can't he get Willian playing as he did under Jose Mourinho, why can't he adapt and get the best from N'Golo Kante? If Sarri is the master coach, why does he have a single way of setting up?

Most worryingly, if Sarri-ball needs time, then he is at the wrong club, because time is the one luxury Chelsea managers never get. Not from the players, certainly not from the owner who has now suffered his first defeat by a four-goal margin since arriving at Stamford Bridge in 2003.

Equally, if Sarri truly believes motivation is Chelsea's only problem that is problematic, because it sounds as if the willingness to make even a small alteration is not there.

So Chelsea sink or swim as they are. That may make Sarri a principled coach, but it doesn't necessarily make him a great one.

Stan's rams offer Arsenal no hope

That the dead hand of Stan Kroenke's stewardship has not been able to prevent the Los Angeles Rams contesting the Super Bowl on Sunday is testament to the rules the NFL have in place to ensure open competition.

If similar incentives were in place here, there might be hope for Arsenal. Too bad they are part of the protectionist cartel, seeking only to keep an established elite in place.

Warnock must not blame himself over the Sala tragedy

Sadly, Neil Warnock still feels guilt over not inviting Emiliano Sala to Newcastle two weekends ago. Had he gone, had he made the trip to watch his new Cardiff team-mates, then Sala would not have returned to Nantes to say goodbye to old friends and would not have disappeared from the radar in poor weather, inside a small plane, with its pilot Dave Ibbotson.

Deep down, Warnock must know he isn't really to blame. It's sliding doors. Whenever a tragic event occurs we imagine the twists and turns, the little decisions that could have prevented it. That train which was missed, the one that was caught, how different would a life have turned out?

Had Warnock insisted his new signing traveled north with the team, he would have saved him — but how could he have known that?

The night Harry Redknapp's best friend from Bournemouth, Brian Tiler, died in a road accident, the pair had swapped seats on their minibus. Redknapp had kept the group waiting and, to jokingly punish him, Tiler took his favourite pew. Redknapp survived the head-on collision, Tiler died. It took him a long time to come to terms with that.

There have been all manner of reports emanating from Cardiff since Sala's disappearance — that the club will demand an investigation into how their player came to be flying in an unsuitable craft in treacherous conditions, that they are considering a compensatory claim of negligence to recoup £14million losses. Warnock, understandably, does not appear very interested in any of it.

Yet there will be an appropriate time for reflection one day, not just for Warnock, or Cardiff, but for everyone in football and a question that may be asked is: when football clubs invest in employees to the tune of millions of pounds, is it not strange that they do not also assume control of other areas of their professional lives?

Cardiff offered to bring back Sala from Nantes, but would only do so on commercial flights. Might they have been more insistent had they known the alternate arrangement being made? Might decisions be made to minimise risk over the cars players drive, the flights they take, the pace of the lifestyle the modern game gives them? Sergio Aguero had a crash speeding to catch a private plane after attending a pop concert in a foreign country.

A specialist insurance broker exists for footballers who wish to buy cars they would never otherwise be allowed to drive. The money affords a glamorous life, maybe it should also afford wise counsel.

What befell Sala was a tragic accident and nobody's fault, but that is not the same as saying it could not have been avoided.

Fellaini: Not pretty, but pretty effective

Marouane Fellaini's departure is being heralded as further evidence of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's positive influence on Manchester United.

Never a United player was the collective wisdom as Fellaini left for China. He seemingly embodied all that was wrong with previous, failed, unpopular regimes.

A little unfair, that. It wasn't just Jose Mourinho who came to lean on Fellaini in a crisis. David Moyes brought him to the club and, if anything, his best years were under Louis van Gaal when he was used in a very unorthodox fashion as an advanced midfield target man.

United would go long, but to Fellaini, not a forward, and he would hold the ball up in a deep, central position. It wasn't necessarily the United way but it was, for a while, very effective. As was throwing Fellaini on late to cause carnage in the box, and nick a late winner.

It is Marcus Rashford's wonderful skill that wins the Europa League quarter-final with Anderlecht in 2017, but it is Fellaini's presence in the box that tees him up.

He was significant throughout that successful run, not least in the final with Ajax, and on a number of occasions came to United's rescue.

No, United do not play that way any longer. If Solskjaer wanted to put it in the mixer — and he probably doesn't — he has two significant upgrades on Fellaini in Paul Pogba and Romelu Lukaku.

Yet there was something about Fellaini, an awkwardness, an ungainly physicality that presented a unique challenge. He had that old cliche, good feet for a big man, too. Fellaini might not be missed as United march towards their sunlit uplands under Solskjaer, but it would be churlish to suggest he never brought anything to the party. He did, but it wasn't pretty.

Why can't Eddie try something different?

England are unlikely to win in Dublin on Saturday but that does not mean Eddie Jones's attempts to revolutionise rugby thinking are wrong.

By starting Jack Nowell at wing, with the freedom to join as a flanker would at the breakdown, he is at least challenging rugby's orthodoxy, and the rigidly enforced player roles.

Why, in theory, can't Nowell operate as a back or a forward? Why was it dismissed as little more than another Jones gimmick when he first floated the idea?

'Are you taking the p*** out of us,' asked one writer when Jones mentioned how he saw Nowell.

No, he wasn't, but to an outsider, it does seem like taking the p*** that a rugby coach has to name his starting XV, and replacements, three days before an important game, a showing of the hand that seems an anathema now the game is wholly professional.

Why can't Jones keep a plan up his sleeve, why can't a coach react to the conditions? Jones wants his wingers to come infield, so to have Nowell shadowing at open-side flanker is merely an extension of that.

It is also a means of holding a tactical ploy back from the opposition, of leaving them unsure how or where Nowell will play. Now imagine that strategy if it only became apparent an hour before the game.

That there was no advance warning in selection, no advance publicity at all. That a rugby coach could shock as a football coach can, by using a player in an innovative fashion, by refusing to conform to convention?

England look to be over-matched by an Irish team that may yet end the year as world champions — in which case a smart coach needs all the help he can get. Breaking free of rugby's traditional expectations could be a start.

It looks like Ole is lucky in general...

The sight of Neymar on crutches and out of Paris Saint-Germain's Champions League tie with Manchester United reminded of Napoleon's observation that he would rather have lucky generals than good ones. Maybe, in Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, United have unearthed both.

item.title: Reading winning battle to keep hold of Tyler Blackett despite interest from Nottingham Forest and Wigan
item.description: Reading are winning their fight to keep hold of Tyler Blackett on deadline day amid interest from Wigan and Nottingham Forest. Blackett has been in demand this month.
item.content:encoded:
Reading are winning their fight to keep hold of Tyler Blackett on deadline day amid interest from Wigan and Nottingham Forest.

Blackett has been in demand this month after an excellent first half of the season.

Wigan have made three bids to sign the former Manchester United defender who can operate at centre half or left back.

Reading rejected their top offer of £500,000 and Wigan boss Paul Cook signed Danny Fox from Forest, which sparked a move by Martin O'Neill for Blackett.

But, having sold Tiago Ilori to Sporting Lisbon, the Royals have been determined to keep the 24-year-old at the Madejski Stadium.

Reading are fighting to avoid relegation from Championship and are currently one point from safety in 22nd place.

item.title: Maurizio Sarri finds his job at Chelsea on the line after thumping defeat at the hands of Bournemouth
item.description: MATT LAWTON: Maurizio Sarri is battling to save his job after Chelsea were thrashed 4-0 at Bournemouth on Wednesday night. Fans booed the Italian after the full-time whistle.
item.content:encoded:
Maurizio Sarri is battling to save his job after Chelsea were thrashed 4-0 at Bournemouth on Wednesday night.

The Italian, brought in from Napoli in the summer to replace Antonio Conte, has been under pressure with his team falling well adrift in the title race and Wednesday night’s reverse saw them drop out of the top four.

Josh King scored either side of a fine David Brooks goal at the Vitality Stadium, before Charlie Daniels added a fourth as Eddie Howe’s team condemned the visitors to a second consecutive Premier League defeat.

Following the match, Sarri said: 'I feel frustrated. Not under pressure. I didn't see the signal of my work. So I am frustrated.

'Maybe it's my fault, maybe I'm not able to motivate them. But the team is very strong, it is also able to win without the coach.'

In response to fans singing 'you don't know what you're doing,' he added: 'We have only to say sorry to our fans. We can lose, of course, in every match, but not in this way. We need to solve the problem. We need to understand where the problem is.'

Sarri had left Callum Hudson-Odoi out of the squad — seen as a rap on the knuckles for the youngster for eyeing a move to Bayern Munich — and new signing Gonzalo Higuain looked horribly out of touch.

With Arsenal leap-frogging Chelsea into the Champions League positions, a place in the Carabao Cup final against Manchester City next month may not be enough to save Sarri given owner Roman Abramovich’s renowned lack of patience.

Chelsea fans turned on him during the game with a chorus of boos after the final whistle.

Sarri was still in the away dressing room with his players 40 minutes after the full-time whistle at the Vitality.

The 60-year-old removed his coaching staff from the room, ensuring it was just himself and his players.

Sarri said: 'In that moment I wanted to talk to them alone, without anybody. I needed to understand, it was so different in the first and second half. I want to try again tomorrow.'

item.title: Liverpool 1-1 Leicester: Jurgen Klopp's side move five points clear but fail to fully capitalise on Manchester City slip up as Harry Maguire's strike cancels out Sadio Mane's early opener
item.description: MARTIN SAMUEL AT ANFIELD: Look, it’s far from the end of the world. This stuff happens in a title race. Good teams drop points, inferiors spring surprises.
item.content:encoded:
Look, it’s far from the end of the world. This stuff happens in a title race. Good teams drop points, inferiors spring surprises. And Leicester aren’t bad, either. The league table on Thursday morning still shows Liverpool five points clear, and what manager wouldn’t take that with 14 games remaining?

Yet there is significance here, too. It isn’t going to be easy. Liverpool can still be caught, can still appear vulnerable. Their last league game here was a 4-3 win over Crystal Palace that was every bit as fraught as it sounds; as was this.

Anyone imagining that Manchester City’s defeat at Newcastle had as good as decided the title race was always likely to be in for a rude awakening. Maybe we just thought Liverpool’s twitch would come later rather than sooner.

MATCH FACTS, PLAYER RATINGS, LEAGUE TABLE AND MATCH ZONE

LIVERPOOL: (4-2-3-1) Alisson 6; Henderson 6, Matip 6, Van Dijk 6.5, Robertson 6; Wijnaldum 7, Keita 6 (Fabinho 72mins 6); Firmino 6, Shaqiri 6 (Lallana 72mins 6), Mane 8; Salah 7

SUBS NOT USED: Mignolet (GK); Lovren, Origi, Camacho

GOALS: Mane (3)

BOOKINGS: Matip (16)

COACH: Jurgen Klopp 6

LEICESTER: (4-2-3-1) Schmeichel 6; Pereira 7, Maguire 8, Evans 7, Chilwell 8; Ndidi 7, Mendy 6; Gray 7 (Okazaki 84mins), Maddison 7 (Choudhury 75mins), Albrighton 7; Vardy 7.5 (Iheanacho 90mins)

SUBS NOT USED: Ward (GK); Simpson, Morgan, Barnes

GOALS: Maguire (45+1)

BOOKINGS: Maguire (41), Ricardo Pereira (50), Chilwell (90+4)

COACH: Claude Puel 7

REFEREE: Martin Atkinson 6

MAN OF THE MATCH: Ben Chilwell

VENUE: Anfield

ATTENDANCE: 53,092

Sadio Mane (No 10) finished off a wonderfully-worked move to give Liverpool the lead inside three minutes at Anfield. For more of Sportsmail's fantastic MATCH ZONE feature, please click here.


*Ratings done by Dominic King

Bottom line: there are traps everywhere, even for the team in command. Liverpool were up after two minutes here but like City on Tuesday, could not make an early advantage felt.

Leicester, like Newcastle, got back on level terms deservedly and might even had won had Harry Maguire’s header across goal after 54 minutes found team-mate Jonny Evans, and not Roberto Firmino, scrambling it clear amid confusion with goalkeeper Allison.

Leicester squeezed the play quite superbly after half-time. They may well end up Europe this season, if Claude Puel is left to manage the team without constantly having to justify his position.

Liverpool might have had a penalty when Ricardo Pereira appeared to clumsily catch Naby Keita in the 58th minute, but referee Martin Atkinson waved it away.

Maybe next year, with VAR. And maybe next time the tension that engulfed Anfield as the scores stayed level will be eased by a second goal. If it is not, though, expect more of the same. This is a city that yearns for its first title of the Premier League era, for all its talk of history, and is fearful of the choke, for all its bravado.

At half-time, groundsmen cleared the pitch of snow that had fallen just prior to kick-off. All of the pitch? No – just the final third that Liverpool would be attacking. And that might be a simple matter of man power – insufficient numbers and insufficient time to do a proper job.

MARK CLATTENBURG: NABY KEITA FOUL DESERVED A PENALTY

Liverpool should have had a penalty when Naby Keita was brought down.

Ricardo Pereira stepped on Keita's standing foot as he was about to shoot.

These decisions are incredibly difficult for referees because they happen so fast. VAR cannot come quickly enough.

However, Martin Atkinson was right not to send off Harry Maguire in the first half for bringing down Sadio Mane as he was about to run through.

It was not a clear goalscoring opportunity as Mane still had plenty to do.

But nor is it a sign of a football club breezing comfortably towards inevitable glory, confident of sweeping all before them. Liverpool tried to gain a tiny jump on Leicester. Liverpool sought a helping hand.

They know the opposition they have got in Manchester City – a club capable of scoring 30 goals without reply. They know what has happened in the past from strong positions.

The fans chanted the name of former manager Rafa Benitez, thankful for his contribution with Newcastle on Tuesday night – but that was just one game, a mere 90 minutes. It is Jurgen Klopp and his players who must drag this over the line in the remaining 14 fixtures and here was proof if any was required that it is not going to be easy.

The heavy snowfall made for difficult conditions, but one wouldn’t have known that the way Liverpool started. If anything it was like the start Manchester City made at Newcastle, only better.

Not quite as quick to score, mind, but with greater control of the game. City needed lousy defending from Newcastle to take the lead after 24 seconds, for Liverpool, it was almost like Leicester were not there at all.

Their opening goal, scored after two minutes, came after 28 successive Liverpool touches. In that 121-second period, Leicester had the ball once. They were little more than bystanders, witnesses to the best team in the country, as they went about their brilliant business.

The final flourishes were dominated by Sadio Mane. Brave man, Mane. There can’t be too many days like this in the Sedhiou region of Senegal, from where he originates, but he was one of the few out there wearing a short-sleeved shirt in the sub-zero conditions.

With so many passes completed it wouldn’t be right to say he started the move per se, but he started the business end of it. He sent the ball out to Andrew Robertson, who in turn found Firmino, recycling it to Mane once more.

Now inside the Leicester area, Mane cut inside and guided his low shot around Kasper Schmeichel into the far corner. Anfield exploded with joy, and no little relief.

Even a four-point cushion isn’t enough to completely calm the nerves, but an early advantage was just what the doctor ordered: a calming pill. Mane must have felt it, too. He knelt down and kissed the snow-flecked turf.

Liverpool continued to dominate as Leicester initially defended too deep and looked like they might add a second. In the sixth minute, Jordan Henderson – deputising at right back, ever the thinking man’s journeyman – found Mo Salah whose deep cross picked out Firmino, forcing a fine save from Schmeichel. From the corner Mane headed just wide.

Slowly, however, as at Newcastle, the game changed. Leicester came into it, Liverpool failed to capitalise. Joel Matip was booked for a cynical challenge high up the field on Jamie Vardy, who otherwise might have been away. Demarai Gray had a cross-shot saved.

Now Liverpool looked nervy. Goalkeeper Alisson dawdled too long on the ball and had his clearance charged down. It ended up with Marc Albrighton who returned it as a dangerous, deep cross which picked out James Maddison.

If you ever wonder why strikers are paid the most money, here was the answer. The goal was open, the equaliser was on. Yet instead of taking the responsibility, Maddison seemed to want to bring in Vardy instead. His header, which should have been directed towards the gaping target, ended up neither one thing nor the other, and missed.

In the 41st minute, Leicester delivered a cynical payback for Matip’s early offence when Robertson looked to have put Mane in, only for Harry Maguire to tug him back and take the booking for the team. Then, in the final attack of the match, the break-out star of England’s World Cup campaign showed the finer side to his game.

It was a goal from nowhere, but impressively taken. Robertson conceded a free-kick on Leicester’s right flank, which Maddison whipped in. The ball was blocked and cleared, but only as far as left-back Ben Chilwell. He headed it back and suddenly it was with Maguire, in so much space Anfield fondly imagined he must be offside.

Nowhere near. Maguire controlled and slotted the ball past Alisson. Nobody has the title won in January; and nobody wins it smiling and waving happily to the crowd without breaking sweat. As if Klopp needed reminding.

And Leicester aren’t bad, either. The league table on Thursday morning still shows Liverpool five points clear, and what manager wouldn’t take that with 14 games remaining? Yet there is significance here, too. It isn’t going to be easy. Liverpool can still be caught, can still appear vulnerable. Their last league game here was a 4-3 win over Crystal Palace that was every bit as fraught as it sounds; as was this. Anyone imagining that Manchester City’s defeat at Newcastle had as good as decided the title race was always likely to be in for a rude awakening. Maybe we just thought Liverpool’s twitch would come later rather than sooner.

item.title: Tottenham 2-1 Watford: Fernando Llorente and Son Heung-min produce late strikes as Mauricio Pochettino's side salvage three points in front of a sparse Wembley Stadium
item.description: MATT BARLOW AT WEMBLEY: One textbook header from Llorente and all was forgiven. The missed chances, the own goal and the simple fact he was not Harry Kane were all forgotten.
item.content:encoded:
One textbook header from Fernando Llorente and all was forgiven. The missed chances, the own goal and the simple fact he was not Harry Kane were all forgotten.

Less than three minutes were left on the clock when Danny Rose delivered a deep cross from the left. Llorente watched its flight, won his duel with Jose Holebas and guided an expert header past Ben Foster.

As the ball nestled into the net Tottenham went wild. Even Mauricio Pochettino got involved, grabbing the Spanish striker as he ran past him on an adrenaline-fuelled celebration run.

'Normally I never celebrate goals but I felt a little bit of freedom because we deserved to win,' said Spurs boss Pochettino. 'This game was so important. The three points were going to be massive to keep our position in the table – and I was so happy because Fernando worked so hard for the team in the last four games.

'You have to build confidence in a striker and when you are competing behind Harry Kane, one of the best in the world, always you need time and always he has been a fantastic professional.'

Llorente scored in his own goal at Fulham when he came in for Kane, then his goal against Chelsea in the Carabao Cup counted for little.

On Wednesday night, he was guilty of squandering some glorious chances, including one sitter, early in the second half, lifted over the goal with his knee but these agonies were cleansed by his first goal in the Premier League for more than a year.

MATCH FACTS, RATINGS, TABLE AND MATCH ZONE

Tottenham (3-4-2-1): Lloris 5; Alderweireld 6, Sanchez 6, Vertonghen 6 (Lamela 79min); Aurier 5 (Moura 45, 6), Winks 6, Sissoko 5.5 (Trippier 69, 6), Rose 6; Son 7.5, Eriksen 5.5; Llorente 6.

Subs not used: Gazzaniga, Dier, Walker-Peters, Skipp.

Scorer: Son 80, Llorente 87.

Booked: None.

Manager: Mauricio Pochettino 6.

Watford (4-2-2-2): Foster 5.5; Janmaat 6, Mariappa 5.5, Cathcart 5.5, Holebas 6; Cleverley 6 (Wilmot 66, 6.5), Capoue 6; Hughes 6, Pereyra 6; Deulofeu 6.5 (Success 61, 6), Deeney 6.5. Subs not used: Gomes, Britos, Masina, Sema, Quina.

Scorer: Cathcart 38.

Booked: Mariappa, Capoue, Holebas, Success.

Manager: Javi Gracia 6.

Referee: Graham Scott 6.

Attendance: 29,164.

In front of 60,000 empty seats and a Premier League low crowd at their adopted home, Tottenham struggled against Watford's fresh legs, well-organised defensive unit and a familiar threat from set-pieces.

Craig Cathcart struck first for the visitors from a corner, turning up the pressure on Pochettino who had seen his team crash out of two cup competitions in four days.

Hugo Lloris shuffled from his line but without claiming the cross from Holebas and Cathcart won a battle of strength with Davinson Sanchez off to head the ball in.

Cathcart had scored the winner against them at Vicarage Road in September as Watford came from behind to win 2-1 with both goals from set-pieces.

Pochettino sent on Lucas Moura for Serge Aurier at the interval, and switched Moussa Sissoko to wing-back.

Tottenham performed with greater urgency but Watford, without a win at Wembley this century, worked hard to defend their lead and Foster was making saves like a goalkeeper destined not to be beaten.

Llorente's miss early in the second half left him with his head in his hands. Sissoko's cross from the right was diverted by Adrian Mariappa towards his own goal and Foster made a brilliant reflex save to keep it out.

The rebound spun in the air towards the Spurs striker at an awkward height and he opted to go for goal with his right knee.

He was only six yards out but somehow lifted it over. Moments later another chance came and went when he headed wide at the near post and fans groaned.

Ben Wilmot cleared off the line to deny Rose and Foster scrambled back to turn over a miscued cross from Harry Winks.

Tottenham were running low on time, within 10 minutes of a third successive defeat when Son Heung-min sparked the late escape.

Llorente dribbled the ball into a crowded penalty area and an attempted clearance by Holebas spilled to Son who lashed an equaliser past Ben Foster with his left foot.

This time last week he was in the desert on international duty in the Asian Cup, and only returned at the weekend after South Korea's exit in the quarter-finals and gave his team a much-needed lift.

'It wasn't the plan to play him for 90 minutes, but the result meant we had to take the risk,' said Pochettino. 'He finished very tired and we will see if he is OK to start the next game.

'It was a great goal and an amazing effort. From the beginning he showed energy. I am happy with his performance but more happy because he showed massive commitment.'

Spurs to their credit refused to settle for a point. They have not drawn a game in the Premier League all season and on they pressed aware that the race for the top four is becoming very congested.

Turning defeat and no points into victory and three could prove to be a crucial moment in the campaign for Pochettino's team.

item.title: Everton renew interest in Michy Batshuayi but The Toffees must sign him permanently as they already have Kurt Zouma on loan from Chelsea
item.description: Everton have renewed their interest in Chelsea striker Michy Batshuayi but the Toffees will not be able to loan him. Marco Silva's side have already loaned Kurt Zouma from the Blues.
item.content:encoded:
Everton have renewed their interest in Chelsea striker Michy Batshuayi but the Toffees will not be able to loan him.

Marco Silva's side have already loaned Kurt Zouma from the Blues and Premier League rules state clubs cannot loan more than player from another Premier League club at one time.

Batshuayi is currently on loan at Valencia and has not started a lague game for the La Liga side since October.

The Belgium international has only managed one goal in 15 league games and three in 23 appearances in all competitions.

The 25-year-old flourished on loan at Borussia Dortmund in the second half of last campaign scoring seven goals in 10 Bundesliga games.

Everton will be hoping he can rediscover that form as Silva targets someone who can be a focal point for his side.

Richarlison has often played up front on his own but his best position is considered to be on the left wing.

While Cenk Tosun has struggled to hold down the position and holds a similar goalscoring record this season to Batshuayi - two goals in 20 appearances in all competitions.

The Blues signed Batshuayi for £33million in 2016 from Marseille and he has yet to show the sort of form for the Ligue 1 club that got him the move to England.

item.title: Tottenham hope to send Vincent Janssen out on loan but Real Betis move hinges on Lucas Perez deal
item.description: Tottenham are trying to get striker Vincent Janssen out on loan before Thursday's transfer deadline, but are running out of suitors for the Dutchman. Real Betis want the forward, but are also in for Lucas Perez.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham are trying to get striker Vincent Janssen out on loan before Thursday's transfer deadline, but are running out of suitors for the Dutchman.

La Liga outfit Real Betis had registered their interest but are also vying for the signature of West Ham's Lucas Perez with Schalke.

Should Perez prefer a return to Spain, that would likely sink any deal to take Janssen to Betis.

Meanwhile, Spurs winger Georges Kevin Nkoudou also lets set to leave and is in talks to join Monaco on loan for the rest of the season.

Manager Mauricio Pochettino was willing to let the Frenchman go despite figuring in recent squads and playing a role in the recent 2-1 win over Fulham at Craven Cottage.

A number of Premier League and Championship sides had considered the 23-year-old but he is now set to link up with new Monaco coach Leonardo Jardim.

item.title: George Groves was the most idiosyncratic of world champions and will be missed in retirement... you suspect deep down Carl Froch will miss him, too
item.description: JEFF POWELL: Thirty is an early age to mellow but even Froch's little jibe about how he and boxing would not miss him failed to provoke even a hint of angst in Groves. But he was in forgiving mood.
item.content:encoded:
George Groves was in forgiving mood on the first official day of his retirement.

Saint by nickname and Saint by nature, Groves smiled back on his arch rivalries with Carl Froch and James DeGale.

Thirty is an early age to mellow but even Froch's little jibe about how he and boxing would not miss him failed to provoke even a hint of angst in Groves.

Mild irony was as spicy as it got, Groves thanking US legend Andre Ward for 'coming to my defence' on Twitter.

'Froch is an intelligent man,' he added. 'He apologised after taking a lot of stick for saying that. But he knows he was the one who beat me twice, second time with that spectacular knock out in front of 80,000 at Wembley, and walked away with the world championship belts.

'And, yes, he was the best boxer I fought.' So, better than Callum Smith who relieved him of the WBA world title, with which he had gone on to crown his career, in what has turned out to be his last fight?

Yes, partly because Groves knew even before they made that trek into the Saudi Arabian desert last September that the World Series tournament final would be his last fight.

The Saint's fighting heart was no longer fully in it, nor his partially repaired shoulder although he refused to blame the injury for that final stoppage.

'Callum was the better man and deserved to win, ' he said. 'All credit to him for beating me when I really wanted to go out in glory with victory and as world champion.'

Not until this week did Groves make it official but now he reveals: 'I was always going to retire after that fight, win, lose or draw.'

A number of factors played into that decision. Not least the brain injury sustained by Edouard Gutknecht in the fight before Groves best Fedor Chudinov to win his WBA super middleweight title.

'The desire was gone after that,' he says. 'After that I only took the few nights necessary to fulfill my ambitions and make my money - before stepping down to spend some of my better years with my wife and two sons as a young man still relatively undamaged.'

Froch better, too, than DeGale? Yes again. Not only because he beat him but because Groves acknowledges Chunky's Olympic gold talent.

'He's very good,' says Groves. 'Even though he's such a nightmare to deal with that when I thought we had once come to terms for a fight when we bumped into each other at Westfield he wrecked it by trying to change it all next day.'

That rematch will never happen now, even though there had been speculation Groves would grant the chance of revenge if DeGale wins his upcoming fight against Chris Eubank Jr.

A little more gentle irony from the Saint as he says: 'I will never come back now even though we could both make a lot more money. I don't need it and it makes me smile that he won't be getting it either before he retires.

'But there will be no problem when I bump into him and Froch at ringsides in the future.'

So what will George do next? 'I want to see if I can be great at something else,' he says. 'Maybe I can be as good at managing young boxers as I was at managing my own career.

He is also branching out into broadcast commentary and motivational speaking.

He says: 'I want to stay around boxing. But the only thing I will miss about being a fighter is the camaraderie in the gym.'

As for boxing and those of us who charted his noble career, we will miss one of the most idiosyncratic of world champions.

And I suspect that deep down Carl Froch will miss him, too.

item.title: Nicola Adams to become first female boxer ever to fight at the Royal Albert Hall when she challenges WBO world flyweight champion Arely Mucino
item.description: Nicola Adams will become the first female boxer ever to fight in the historic setting of the Royal Albert Hall when she challenges WBO world flyweight champion Arely Mucino on March 8.
item.content:encoded:
Nicola Adams will become the first female boxer ever to fight in the historic setting of the Royal Albert Hall when she challenges WBO world flyweight champion Arely Mucino on March 8.

This will be the first world title fight for Adams, who became the first woman Olympic champion when she won the first of her two golds at the London Games.

As she gazed around the setting she said: 'I love making history and it will be an honour for me to follow in the footsteps of so many great boxers who have fought here.'

Boxing first took place at the Albert Hall a hundred years ago, in December 1918.

Professional fights were not permitted until the early 1920s, after which Muhammad Ali boxed two exhibition bouts and Primo Carnera, Georges Carpentier, Henry Cooper, Frank Bruno, Lennox Lewis, Ricky Hatton, Naseem Hamed and Marco Antonio Barrera were among those who starred under the chandeliers.

Heavyweight prospect Daniel Dubois will also be on the bill as promoter Frank Warren brings boxing back to the Albert Hall for only the second time in the last 20 years.

item.title: Leading rugby nations gather for talks about new competition... and World Rugby are keen to see relegation introduced in the Six Nations
item.description: The world's leading rugby nations are planning further talks about meeting to discuss a new global competition, with countries from both the southern and northern hemisphere keen to make it happen.
item.content:encoded:
The world's leading rugby nations are planning further talks about meeting to discuss a new global competition, with countries from both the southern and northern hemisphere keen to make it happen.

But sources insisted on Tuesday night there remain a number of sticking points, with the Six Nations representatives and World Rugby already on a collision course over the issue of relegation from the championship.

Sportsmail revealed last week that officials from all the Tier One nations were planning to discuss the radical plan for an annual World Rugby Nations Championship with World Rugby and Six Nations officials, with one concern for rugby fans the potential for a major new broadcast deal that spells the end of international rugby on terrestrial TV.

But insiders revealed on Tuesday that the talks were positive, and spoke of a collective desire to continue exploring the concept even if agreement still needs to be reached in some areas for a competition that would run every year except Rugby World Cup year.

While World Rugby would like to see relegation from the Guinness Six Nations Championship that then creates new opportunities for the developing rugby countries, Sportsmail understands that the Six Nations hierarchy and member unions are resolutely against the concept of promotion and relegation.

Further to that, it has also been made clear that the kind of figures being mooted in terms of TV revenue need to be higher. 'The offer is not good enough,' said one source.

It is also believed the RFU will need to secure agreement from the English clubs and they may not countenance two extra Test weeks in autumn.

A World Rugby spokesperson said: 'Following positive and productive meetings with union and competition CEOs in Los Angeles, World Rugby has been tasked to continue exploring the viability of potential global competition formats.

'The objective of this exploratory work is to deliver a global competition product and commercial model that will deliver greater value and certainty to all unions by building on the strong foundations of existing competitions and invigorating the July and November windows.

'World Rugby would like to thank the stakeholders involved for their contribution to this important project that has the clear potential to enhance the international game for unions, players and fans.'

item.title: Manchester United 2-2 Burnley: Victor Lindelof scrambles home in stoppage time to rescue Ole Gunnar Solskjaer from shock defeat
item.description: IAN LADYMAN AT OLD TRAFFORD: This was a poor result for United. Draws at home to teams from the wrong end of the Premier League do not generally take big clubs where they want to go.
item.content:encoded:
On the face of it, this was a poor result for Manchester United. Draws at home to teams from the wrong end of the Premier League do not generally take big clubs where they want to go.

But at United now mood is everything and the manner in way this point was won will not do Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and his players very much harm at all.

United were poor and did not deserve much. All the big performances came from Burnley. Goalkeeper Tom Heaton – once of United – was magnificent and central defenders Ben Mee and James Tarkowski were not very far behind.

Two goals to the good with three minutes of regulation time to go, Sean Dyche’s team should have won and would have done had Jeff Hendrick not fouled Jesse Lingard in the penalty area when he really didn’t have to.

It was soft but it was a penalty all the same. And when Paul Pogba swept in the kick, United swarmed all over Burnley like teams of yore.

Such was the ferocious, irresistable nature of the assault that followed, the only surprise was that Solskjaer’s team only scored one more.

By the end of five minutes of added time, Dyche’s players were hanging on like castaways clinging to a rock.

MATCH FACTS, RATINGS, TABLE AND MATCH ZONE

MANCHESTER UNITED (4-2-3-1): De Gea 6; Young 6, Lindelof 6, Jones 6, Shaw 6; Matic 6, Pereira 5.5 (Lingard 62min, 6) Rashford 6, Pogba 6.5, Mata 6.5; Lukaku 6.5 (Sanchez 67, 6). Subs not used: Smalling, Fred, Dalot, Herrera, Romero.

Scorers: Pogba 87 (pen), Lindelof 90+2. Booked: Mata.

Manager: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer 6.

BURNLEY (4-4-2): Heaton 8.5; Bardsley 7.5, Tarkowski 8, Mee, Taylor 8; Hendrick 7.5, Cork 7, Westwood 7, McNeill 7 (Gudmundsson 76, 6); Barnes 7.5, Wood 7.

Subs not used: Vokes, Gibson, Hart, Ward, Vydra, Benson.

Scorers: Barnes 51, Wood 81.

Booked: Barnes, Taylor, Cork.

Manager: Sean Dyche 8.

Referee: Jon Moss 6.

Attendance: 74,529.

Forget for a moment the barren years of Jose Mourinho, Louis van Gaal and David Moyes, this was a finale taken straight from the Sir Alex Ferguson play book.

Where it leaves United is in touching distance of the top four and, crucially, unbeaten under Solskjaer. As such they will head to Leicester on Sunday feeling like the wind is still at their backs.

At times like this, when things are so delicately balanced, it can just take a single goal to determine a mood, a direction of travel. By the season’s end, Victor Lindelof’s equaliser may yet feel like a very big goal indeed.

Certainly it was at odds with the general manner of United’s performance. Speed, tempo and purpose have characterised United’s football under Solskjaer. Here, these qualities were lacking against a Burnley team that was dogged but also ambitious and impressively clinical in front of goal.

In the first half, the best chances were United’s but there weren’t many. Marcus Rashford fluffed a very good opportunity after Romelu Lukaku played him in while Heaton saved brilliantly from Lukaku only for the Belgian to discover he was offside.

At the other end, there had been some moments of hope for Burnley, not least when Phil Jones was forced to clear the ball off Ashley Barnes’ toe in the 17th minute.

United needed to improve but by the time they did they were two down.

Heaton began the second half well with saves from Juan Mata and Pogba before Burnley pounced on a moment of hesitancy in the United half to steal the lead.

A ball from Jones to Andreas Pereira put the young midfielder under a little pressure and when Jack Cork stole possession, he fed Barnes on his left and the first time rising shot from the Burnley striker gave David de Gea no chance in the United goal.

With almost 40 minutes still to play, the smart money would still not have been on Burnley. But for subsequent periods it began to feel as though Heaton – with the help of what began to resembled a back five in front of him – may be about to see Dyche’s team home.

Heaton is currently keeping two fine goalkeepers – Joe Hart and Nick Pope –out of the Burnley team and he was fabulous here, both in terms of his athleticism and command of his penalty area.

And when Chris Wood headed in an Ashley Westwood cross before the Stretford End with nine minutes to go, Heaton may just have thought he was about to win at the club where he started his career.

The crucial subsequent moment was the concession of the penalty. It was only a hand on Lingard’s shoulder from Hendrick but it was enough.

Pogba’s penalty was struck true and when five minutes of added time were signalled it was not hard to see where this game was heading.

Heaton still had time to contribute two more saves.

The first, from a Pogba curler, looked as though it may have won the game but when he dropped to save an Alexis Sanchez header at the far post in the 92nd minute, even he couldn’t prevent Lindelof smashing the equaliser in from just a yard.

United actually recovered a 2-0 deficit to draw against Burnley at Old Trafford last season, too. That, it transpired, was not a result that led to very much. If Solskjaer is to earn himself the big job for the long term between now and May, it must be different this time.

item.title: Newcastle 2-1 Manchester City: Rafa Benitez's men stun Pep Guardiola's side as Salomon Rondon and Matt Ritchie seal comeback to dent City's title hopes
item.description: MARTIN SAMUEL AT ST JAMES' PARK: It is not over, but if Liverpool do their job at home on Wednesday, the gap at the top will be seven - an advantage any good team should hope to close out.
item.content:encoded:
It is not over, but it is harder, from here. If Liverpool do their job at home to Leicester on Wednesday, and there is no reason why they should not, with such a weight off, the gap at the top will be seven points. Not insurmountable, but an advantage that any good team should hope to close out. And Liverpool are a good team.

So are Manchester City, but not on Tuesday night. Given every advantage against a struggling Newcastle side, they failed to take the game on, much less the challenge.

Credit Rafael Benitez for that, of course. He sets his teams up well and despite the hindrance of conceding after just 24 seconds, ensured his players remained in the game long enough to win it. Newcastle were not lucky, or undeserving.

MATCH FACTS, LIVE LEAGUE TABLE AND MATCH ZONE

NEWCASTLE UTD (5-3-1-1): Dubravka 6; Yedlin 6, Schar 6, Lascelles 6, Lejeune 6, Ritchie 7; Hayden 6, Longstaff 7, Atsu 7 (Kenedy 87); Perez 6.5 (Manquillo 90+1); Rondon 7.5.

Subs not used: Woodman, Clark, Murphy, Fernandez, Roberts.

Scorers: Rondon 66, Ritchie 80 pen.

Booked: Schar, Perez.

Manager: Rafa Benitez 7.5.

MANCHESTER CITY (4-3-3): Ederson 6; Walker 6, Stones 6.5, Laporte 6, Danilo 6 (Gundogan 83); De Bruyne 6.5 (B Silva 65, 6), Fernandinho 5.5, D. Silva 6; Sterling 6, Aguero 6.5, Sane 5.5 (Jesus 73, 5.5).

Subs not used: Muric, Foden, Otamendi, Mahrez.

Scorer: Aguero 1.

Booked: De Bruyne, Sterling, Laporte.

Manager: Pep Guardiola 6.

Referee: Paul Tierney 6.

Attendance: 50,861.

Manchester City did not have too many chances and Newcastle more than matched their intensity. The winning penalty was deserved and the equalising goal every bit as sloppy from City’s perspective as the opener was from Newcastle’s.

As the game slipped away, the usually effervescent Pep Guardiola slumped in his seat and sucked on a water bottle, plainly furious. This was one of City's poorest performances of the season, at a time when they could afford it least.

Newcastle, meanwhile, can take great heart from a result that propels them to 14th in the table. They needed it, too, considering the scorelines – Fulham’s revival against Brighton, Burnley’s draw at Old Trafford. Yet these were the unlikeliest points of all, given City’s form going into this match.

They had scored 29 goals without reply across all competitions before this – breaking a record held by Preston North End from Queen Victoria’s day. And when the 30th took just 24 seconds to arrive, few gave Newcastle a prayer of holding out the remaining 89 minutes and 36 seconds without letting in at least one more.

The spikiness of their reaction, then – particularly given the difficult circumstances surrounding the club, with mutinous cries against owner Mike Ashley a permanent backdrop – is to be admired. True, in the second half before Newcastle scored, goalkeeper Martin Dubravka had made two impressive saves, from Raheem Sterling and David Silva, but even for the long periods when City led and looked comfortable, Newcastle were not out of it.

They should have been, though, given the events in the first minute. The talk pre-match was of Miguel Almiron, a Paraguayan midfield player arriving from Atlanta United for a fee in the region of £20m – a new club record. If reports are correct, he will have his medical in the next 48 hours. Judging by the first minute, however, reinforcements of any description cannot come soon enough.

No doubt Benitez’s gameplan involved keeping it tight against a team that is prolific in front of goal. If so, oh Lordy. It was Manchester City’s fastest goal since Jesus Navas scored after 13 seconds against Tottenham in November 2013 and the fastest of the Premier League season so far. What were Newcastle thinking?

Raheem Sterling floated in a straightforward deep cross from the right. No defender dealt with it and it was left to goalkeeper Dubravka to smother at the far post. It was hard to see whether David Silva bravely stooped in to head the ball back across goal, or lost his footing and gamely improvised.

Either way, it had a double whammy effect – the header finding Sergio Aguero and the effort taking Silva into Dubravka and the goalkeeper out of the game. Even that might not have been calamitous had any Newcastle defender been capable of standing up to Aguero. No chance.

Benitez looked disgusted. Yet, by the end of the half, so did Guardiola. He probably couldn’t believe it took his team until the 44th minute to get in behind Newcastle again, when Leroy Sane had a header from a Danilo cross cleared off the line.

Adding to the frustration would have been an incident in the 17th minute when Sterling was upended and Kevin De Bruyne stood over the free-kick. Referee Paul Tierney may have told him to wait for the whistle, but De Bruyne whipped in a lovely ball that Aguero turned in at the far post. No goal – but to add insult to injury, Tierney then booked De Bruyne for jumping the gun.

Quite how the team that had been wronged ended up with a yellow card, and the team that committed the foul received all the time in the world to regroup and repel, is a mystery that football’s authorities should address at the earliest opportunity.

In the meantime, Newcastle were slowly coming into it. Ayoze Perez gave City a scare, catching Danilo in possession and haring towards goal, before screwing his low shot wastefully wide. Soon after Salomon Rondon set up Christian Atsu, whose shot was deflected high into the night sky by John Stones, the ball coming to rest on the roof of the City net.

Still no upping of the ante from City, which is how, in the 66th minute, Newcastle could equalise. From Guardiola’s point of view, the goal was an utter shambles. A header clear went as far as Isaac Hayden, who returned it with a looping header of his own. City reacted dismally, lacking urgency or appealing fruitlessly for offside. Amid the confusion, Salomon Rondon stayed calm. As the ball dropped, he struck it with his right foot, powering it into the ground and on a cold night with a hard surface, sending it over goalkeeper Ederson, in one mighty bounce.

Even then, the money was on City. Newcastle’s equaliser would be a wake-up call, teasing the monster out of the champions. There were 24 minutes to go and they had previously only needed 24 seconds. It was show time. Instead, Newcastle scored a second.

Fernandinho was caught in possession, panicked and sent Sean Longstaff tumbling. Tierney quite rightly pointed to the spot. Matt Ritchie stepped up to take it but, first, an unwelcome interlude. Ederson required treatment. A real injury? A psychological ploy? Who knew?

The wait must have seemed interminable, not just here at St James’ Park but over on Merseyside, the time and tension as Ritchie stood over the ball with Newcastle, and Liverpool, fans waiting for the denouement must have stretched across an agonising age. If Ritchie scored, and Newcastle held on, January 29, 2019, could become the day Liverpool’s first Premier League title at last felt like reality.

And score, he did. Ritchie held his nerve and slipped the ball under Ederson, to his right. City stumbled when it was least expected. This was supposed to be the match in which they shifted the pressure to Liverpool. Played first, won, and closed the gap to a single point. Over to you, Jurgen. Instead, it was City that were found wanting; and may not get the chance to close again.

item.title: Brentford forward Ollie Watkins set to escape ban despite accusations he dived to win a penalty against Barnet
item.description: Ollie Watkins is set to escape a ban despite accusations he dived to win a penalty in Brentford's FA Cup fourth round tie at Barnet. The FA's disciplinary chiefs intend to take no further action.
item.content:encoded:
Ollie Watkins is set to escape a ban despite accusations he dived to win a penalty in Brentford's FA Cup fourth round tie at Barnet.

The Football Association's disciplinary chiefs intend to take no further action against Watkins after examining footage of the incident from the second half of the 3-3 draw at the Hive on Monday.

Non-league Barnet were leading 2-1 against their Championship opponents when Watkins appeared to be tripped in the box by full-back David Tutonda.

Referee Andrew Madley awarded a penalty and it was converted by Neal Maupay to level the scores but television replays showed there had been no contact.

Barnet manager Darren Currie described it as a "wonderful dive" and revealed after the match that Watkins had apologised to Tutonda.

Brentford boss Thomas Frank defended his young player and insisted Watkins was "no diver".

Frank's team went 3-2 up before Dan Sparks curled in a free-kick 15 minutes from time to force a replay next week at Griffin Park.

The winners of the tie will be away at Swansea in the fifth round.

The FA introduced a rule at the start of last season in an attempt to crack down on the proliferation of diving with a system of retrospective punishment, although it has been very rarely implemented.

Oumar Niasse and Manuel Lanzini among the first to be banned. It has, however, proved difficult to be certain of intent to deceive.

item.title: 'I am the first that wants to win': Mauricio Pochettino insists he DOES care about winning trophies as the Tottenham boss launches passionate defence of his work at the club
item.description: Mauricio Pochettino launched a passionate defence of his work and hailed his Tottenham players as 'heroes', despite crashing out of two cup competitions in four days.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham boss Mauricio Pochettino rolled up his sleeves and came out swinging at those who dared to accuse him of not caring about trophies.

Pochettino launched a passionate defence of his work and hailed his players as 'heroes', despite crashing out of two cup competitions in four days.

And he called for supporters to unite behind the team, starting against Watford at Wembley on Wednesday. 'The club needs the help of the fans because they are the core and the soul of the club and this is a massive moment,' he said.

'All together we need the last push to finish in the top four or maybe be a real contender.

'Then, playing in the Champions League is an exciting moment for the club. We have ahead two massive challenges — Champions League and Premier League.'

Pochettino referred to almost two years without a stadium and the injury crisis which has left him without Harry Kane, Dele Alli and others.

'With all the problems we are still fighting,' said the Spurs boss, who has Son Heung-min and Moussa Sissoko back in contention to face Watford.

'When you lose, everything starts to be negative, but look how thin the line was. Win on penalties (at Chelsea) and we're talking about a final.

'If Kieran Trippier scores the penalty (at Crystal Palace) and maybe we're still in the FA Cup and talking about the character of the team.'

He urged fans to 'have faith' and 'keep fighting' in the quest to reach 'the last level' when new players say they are signing for the club 'to win titles'.

Though it seems unlikely any new players will arrive in this transfer window, as Pochettino admitted: 'A few days ago I was very optimistic about some options to sign — realistic options to sign — but today no, I'm not optimistic.'

Yet progress, he insisted, was ahead of schedule on the brief given when he arrived in 2014 to deliver Champions League football in time for the new stadium.

And he spoke at length about the 'big picture' but dismissed the idea he did not care about the domestic cups. 'Football is about winning,' said Pochettino.

'I am not a naive person. I want to build my own c.v. by winning titles. I am the first that wants to win.

'In the last five years we played in four semi-finals and one final. We were there, close.'

The new £850million stadium at White Hart Lane and regular Champions League football will deliver prestige and financial clout and may attract and keep players.

Over time, he believes these things will bring them closer in line with European giants such as Real Madrid and enable Tottenham to be 'a contender for every single title'.

All of which begged a question about Pochettino's own future at a time when Manchester United and Real Madrid covet him — but this was less clear-cut.

'I am going to stick with the club until the end to help the club achieve all they want,' he said at one point.

But, when asked to confirm this meant he would be Spurs' manager next season, he replied: 'I can't promise that.

'It's not only my decision. I signed for five years and am here respecting my contract, but in football to sign a five-year contract doesn't mean you'll be here for ever.'

item.title: Sorry Mauricio Pochettino, the biggest clubs win cups AND get in the top four
item.description: MARTIN SAMUEL - CHIEF SPORTS WRITER: Spurs were always a big club, because Spurs won trophies. That's what big clubs do. They don't just play in the Champions League each season.
item.content:encoded:
Chas Hodges and Dave Peacock wrote a lot of songs better than their offering for Tottenham's last appearance in an FA Cup final.

They reused the old tune from London Girls, a song released to limited success in 1983, and simply changed the lyrics to celebrate a coincidental strand running through a lot of the club's achievements. It peaked at No 44 in the charts.

(It's Lucky For Spurs) When The Year Ends In One mapped Tottenham's successes through the century, and the fact that the decades had a habit of beginning with a trophy for the club. Their prediction proved right: Tottenham won the FA Cup that year, too — 1991.

It is worth remembering this when considering the club Tottenham are now, and the club they were then. Tottenham were always a big club, because Tottenham won trophies.

That's what big clubs do. They don't just play in the Champions League each season. They win the big matches, they win the big prizes.

Start with the ones Chas and Dave celebrated: FA Cup (1901), FA Cup (1921), League title (1951), League and FA Cup double (1961), League Cup (1971), FA Cup (1981). Then consider the others that don't fit neatly into numerical repetition or a catchy pub rock chorus: FA Cup in 1962, 1967 and 1982; League Cup in 1973 (and later in 1999 and 2008); European Cup-winners' Cup in 1963; UEFA Cup in 1972 and 1984.

Cups are only good for the ego, Mauricio Pochettino says, but that is not the limit of their influence. The reason Tottenham can build, and fill, a 60,000-capacity stadium, the reason they can attract 80,000 to major matches at Wembley, is because they have the fan base of a big club — and they grew that by winning trophies.

Yes, we know, fourth is a trophy these days, too. Can't display it in a cabinet, or parade it on an open-top bus, but it is there on the balance sheet and in the fixture schedule for the new season.

Pochettino is right. Had he won the League Cup and finished consistently mid-table, he would have been sacked. Establishing Tottenham in the Champions League will feel to him as huge as any trophy.

It means Tottenham return to White Hart Lane as a different entity. A big club, yes, but big on numbers, big on paper, not big in the way of a club that wins trophies. Not big like Manchester United, even when they sit outside the top four.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer had it right, again, when asked the extent of his ambition at Manchester United. 'We are looking to win trophies,' he said. 'Top four will never be the dream for Manchester United.'

Of course, that's easy for him to say. At Arsenal on Friday, Solskjaer had the luxury of leaving Marcus Rashford and Anthony Martial to rest on the substitutes' bench, and starting Romelu Lukaku and Alexis Sanchez.

Pochettino by contrast has Harry Kane and Dele Alli out injured, and Son Heung-min returning from international tournament duty with South Korea. Tottenham's resources do not compare to those of Manchester United.

Then again, when did they? When have Tottenham ever been the club with the most money? It has never stopped them before.

Pochettino is deserving of sympathy and no little respect. Everyone acknowledges the job he has done at Tottenham. Yet qualifying for the Champions League and winning a domestic cup competition should not be regarded as mutually exclusive. Other clubs do it, because that is the mark of elite membership.

Since 2002-03 when Premier League entry to the Champions League became a minimum of four clubs each season, five have accounted for 63 of England's places. Arsenal, Manchester United and Chelsea have been in 15 times each, Liverpool on 10 occasions, Manchester City eight.

During that period Chelsea have won five FA Cups and three League Cups, Manchester United two FA Cups and four League Cups, Arsenal five FA Cups, Manchester City one FA Cup and three League Cups and Liverpool one FA Cup and two League Cups. This season's League Cup will go to either Manchester City or Chelsea, too.

So it is possible to remain in the top four and win a cup. It is not just about an ego trip for the manager, or players — it is an intrinsic part of the profile of an elite club.

Tottenham's only trophy in this period is the League Cup in 2008, won before the club began qualifying for the modern Champions League.

Pochettino's implication is that the top-four finish takes it all out of them, and there is no room for anything else. Yet there used to be. In five of their cup-winning seasons, Tottenham finished high enough to have qualified for the modern Champions League.

They won the FA Cup and came third in 1961-62, the European Cup-winners' Cup and second in 1962-63, the FA Cup and third in 1966-67, the League Cup and third in 1970-71 and the FA Cup and fourth in 1981-82.

Was English football any less competitive then? Clubs were often the best in Europe, and the league was certainly more open.

Equally, many more of Tottenham's rivals were as strong financially. Between 1961 and 1982, the British transfer record was broken 14 times — but only once by Tottenham, paying £200,000 for Martin Peters in March 1970. The following year, Arsenal topped that, for Alan Ball. In all, Tottenham were one of 11 English clubs capable of paying a record fee for a player in that period.

The others? Manchester United, Leicester, Leeds, Arsenal, Derby, Everton, West Brom, Nottingham Forest, Manchester City and Wolves. No sovereign wealth funds or oil money, but the competition was certainly out there.

Perhaps what is most dispiriting for any Tottenham fan who dreams of seeing a trophy held aloft at the town hall is that the tournaments that now matter most are the hardest to win.

Tottenham's last league title came in 1961 and in the modern Champions League they have only once reached the last eight, under Harry Redknapp in 2011.

The Pochettino years have been rather underwhelming: a group stage exit followed by defeat against Juventus in the last 16. There have been some great nights — not least the 3-1 home wins over Real Madrid and Borussia Dortmund — but nothing that suggests Tottenham are ready to take on what Pochettino described as the last level.

Their next Champions League opponents are Dortmund, Bundesliga leaders, and much improved in roughly 18 months since their last Wembley visit. In the previous seven seasons, Dortmund have made five appearances in Germany's cup final, winning it twice.

It could be argued this is the more traditional and effective method of muscling in and remaining among elite company. It certainly suggests there is another way.

Hardy made a cock-up, that's all

Modern man, it would seem, divides into two varieties: those who like to keep a picture of their penis handy on a smart-phone, perhaps for special occasions, and those who do not. Alan Hardy, chairman of Notts County, would appear to fall into the first category.

While on Twitter at the weekend, Hardy inadvertently included his phone's picture gallery, and an image he later described as 'inappropriate'. This depends. If the intention was to show that he is probably not the sort of person to be left in charge of the league's oldest football club, or with a camera phone while in the bath, it was entirely appropriate.

Hardy later put the club up for sale, claiming this decision had nothing at all to do with the unexpected appearance of the last turkey in the shop. There, amid much hilarity, is where the matter should end.

But, no. As ever the FA cannot so much as see a nut without reaching for the sledgehammer, and have now asked Hardy for his observations. What is the point of that? It's a mistake. Quite obviously, a mistake.

He didn't tweet a picture of his penis. He tweeted a screenshot that inadvertently included his camera roll which, for reasons unknown, included his penis. What is the FA's purpose here? To issue a charge?

Notts County are in dire financial straits, bottom of League Two. The owner is struggling to keep his club out of the National League and his penis out of the papers.

Surely they, and he, have suffered enough, without the FA's disciplinary department seeking involvement.

Pep continues to make history at City

What have the following clubs got in common: Preston, Sunderland, Aston Villa, Sheffield Wednesday, Liverpool, Huddersfield, Arsenal, Portsmouth, Manchester United, Wolves, Chelsea, Blackburn Rovers, Newcastle, Tottenham and Nottingham Forest? Here's a clue: we could also throw in Wanderers.

The answer is that each of them, at some point in their history, have retained a trophy. Not necessarily the league title — Blackburn, Newcastle and Tottenham have only retained cups — but on occasions something even grander, such as Forest's retention of the main European prize.

Yet there are some notable absences. Everton, for instance — and Manchester City. Meaning if City can overcome Chelsea in the Carabao Cup final next month, it will be the first trophy they have retained in their 124-year history.

That is not to be underestimated; much like City's current run of 29 goals scored across all competitions, without reply. Incredibly, this beats a record that has resided with Preston since 1889-90.

Liverpool may lead the league but, under Pep Guardiola, City continue to make history, and should be admired for that.

It has to be all or nothing when it comes to VAR

The first time Arsenal wore a yellow away shirt was the 1950 FA Cup final against Liverpool. That's how fair the competition used to be.

In the event of a colour clash both teams had to switch to second kit — except Arsenal and Liverpool's away strips clashed, too. So Arsenal changed a second time, wearing yellow shirts, white shorts, and yellow and blue hooped socks.

Yellow eventually became their official change in 1968. Now, the FA Cup is so mixed up even individual ties are subject to different rules.

Some matches have VAR, others do not. Some rounds have replays, others do not. Consistency is a must in football. The mess we saw across fourth round weekend should never be repeated. Either all in with VAR, or nothing. There should not be a ration on truth.

Beth Tweddle, former Olympic gymnast, is suing the makers of television show 'The Jump' having fractured two vertebrae in training in 2016.

Good luck explaining to the judge that she didn't know ski-jumping could be dangerous and came with a risk of personal injury. It would be like suing the BBC because Les Miserables left you feeling a bit fed up.

It is good that Accrington Stanley manager John Coleman apologised to referee Jon Moss, for his outburst at the end of the FA Cup defeat by Derby. Coleman spoke of Moss being arrogant, and making horrendous decisions. He said the official 'scarpered into the lounge' ... 'Our dressing rooms probably weren't good enough for him,' he sneered.

Perhaps having been informed how this was likely to play out at the FA, Coleman later issued a statement expressing regret.

Maybe he had also seen the incident in the 93rd minute, when his player, Sean McConville, committed quite the worst dive of the weekend. Moss ignored him, rather than issuing a yellow card.

When a Premier League player dived we used to hear a lot of moralising about the different standards lower down. Genuine football, full of honest, decent lads, better than these overpaid prima donnas. Wider television coverage has exposed that lie.

McConville's career has taken him from Skelmersdale to Stockport, Rochdale, Barrow, Stalybridge, Chester and now Accrington. He's lower league through and through, but every bit as big a cheat as Luis Suarez was. Just minus the talent.

The fans won't forget, Arnie

Marko Arnautovic may fondly consider he picks up where he left off with West Ham's fans. Unlikely. In the self-serving statement that preceded his new contract signing, he announced: 'Let's focus on the rest of this season together — and let them bubbles fly.'

Leaving aside the extent to which bubbles fly as opposed to float fleetingly before bursting into nothingness, one of the remaining positives of this season for West Ham's faithful was the prospect of an FA Cup run, having drawn AFC Wimbledon, bottom of League One.

West Ham lost on Saturday, with Arnautovic nowhere to be seen. His absence wasn't the only reason for defeat, but it was certainly one of them.

Having presumptuously waved goodbye to the fans once already this season, he might not want to overplay what in his mind will be a heroic return against Liverpool next Monday. They've got long memories around those parts: certainly longer than two weeks.
