item.title: Head of Japan's Olympic Committee under investigation in France for suspected corruption charges in relation to country's successful 2020 bid to host Games in Tokyo
item.description: The head of Japan’s Olympic Committee is being formally investigated by French financial prosecutors over allegations of paying bribes to secure the 2020 Games for Tokyo
item.content:encoded:
The head of Japan’s Olympic Committee is being formally investigated by French financial prosecutors over allegations of paying bribes to secure the 2020 Games for Tokyo

As Sportsmail revealed in 2016, the French authorities had discovered payments from a Japanese bank account called ‘Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games Bid’ to the Singapore-based Black Tidings company at the centre of the corruption scandal in athletics and suspected of laundering money extorted from drug cheats in the sport.

Indeed the national financial parquet (PNF) in Paris confirmed they were examining two payments to a company with links to Papa Massata Diack – the son of former IAAF president Lamine Diack and someone who remains in hiding in Senegal - totalling £1.4million that were made either side of the 2020 Games vote in Buenos Aires in 2013.

In 2016 a Tokyo 2020 spokesperson said ‘the Tokyo 2020 Organising Committee has no means of knowing these allegations’, even though Organising Committee vice-chairman Tsunekazu Takeda had been president of the bid.

But on Friday it emerged that Takeda had been indicted by the PNF, a criminal investigation formally launched last month.

A spokesperson for the French financial prosecutor has confirmed that Takeda, a former Olympian who is also the chairman of the International Olympic Committee’s marketing commission, was charged by an investigating judge on December 10.

In a statement Takeda said he had been questioned by the French authorities but denies the accusations.

On Friday the IOC confirmed that its ethics commission had opened a file on the investigation and will ‘continue to monitor the situation’, adding that ‘Mr Takeda continues to enjoy the full presumption of innocence’.

Tokyo beat rival cities Istanbul and Madrid to host the 2020 Olympic and Paralympic Games.

Tokyo governor Yuriko Koike said she was 'very surprised' by the news of the investigation.

Takeda, 71, has long been involved in the Olympics movement, having competed as a show jumper in the 1972 and 1976 games. His great-grandfather was the Emperor Meiji and he is the current emperor's second cousin.

He has been a member of the Japanese Olympic Committee since 1987 and its president since 2001, helping to coordinate the preparations for several Winter Olympics as a senior member of the International Olympic Committee (IOC).

Takeda attended a ceremony in Tokyo on Friday along with former prime minister Yoshiro Mori, the president of Tokyo 2020, according to Mori's office.

item.title: Blackpool win race to sign Crystal Palace starlet Nya Kirby on loan after seeing off Championship competition
item.description: Palace boss Roy Hodgson was keen to keep him involved at Selhurst Park but understands the 18-year-old is keen to play and that first-team experience is vital to his development.
item.content:encoded:
Blackpool have won the scramble to sign highly-rated teenager Nya Kirby on loan from Crystal Palace.

Kirby has agreed to join the League One club until the end of the season.

Palace boss Roy Hodgson was keen to keep him involved at Selhurst Park but understands the 18-year-old is keen to play and that first-team experience is vital to his development.

Kirby, one of England’s Under 17 World Cup winners, is yet to make his senior debut but was an unused substitute in the Carabao Cup this season.

There was interest from clubs in the Championship but he has opted for Blackpool after meeting with manager Terry McPhillips.

item.title: It is nonsense to say Rory McIlroy owes anything to the European Tour
item.description: MARTIN SAMUEL - CHIEF SPORTS WRITER: The idea McIlroy needs to show greater loyalty to the game on this side of the Atlantic, or risk forfeiting his place in the Ryder Cup team, is just nonsense.
item.content:encoded:
Samuel Ryder did not envisage European competition for the trophy bearing his name. Despite Arnaud Massy, a Frenchman, winning the Open in 1907, there was never any suggestion that the USA would take on an entire continent at golf, when the Ryder Cup was in its formative stages.

Ryder, the tournament's sponsor, did not entertain this, nor did the magazine Golf Illustrated, whose fund-raising for an American raiding party to challenge for the 1921 Open at St Andrews built the momentum and appetite for an international team competition.

Europe's involvement began in 1979, as a consequence of the United States winning 17 of the previous 18 editions against Great Britain and Ireland. Team Europe pretty much hijacked the Ryder Cup at that point, and it is a good job they did.

'A coupla cocktail parties, we kick their butts and go home,' was Tom Kite's description of the pre-European Ryder Cup and ferocious, proud competitors like Seve Ballesteros and Bernhard Langer changed that.

Yet what the Ryder Cup has never really been about is the European Tour itself. That is an even newer sophistication. The idea that Rory McIlroy needs to show greater loyalty to the game on this side of the Atlantic, or risk forfeiting his place in the Ryder Cup team, is just nonsense. McIlroy has nothing to prove whatsoever.

European golfers must be members of the European Tour, which seems reasonable, and the Tour rankings are the fairest way of picking the team. This makes selection a meritocracy and gives European tournaments greater meaning. Again, that is only right.

Yet there the connection ends because, in essence, the Ryder Cup is European-born versus American-born. It is not a battle of the tours. If it were, nationality would not matter. The current leader of the European Tour's Race to Dubai is David Lipsky. He is American.

The 2019 rankings are in their infancy, obviously, and once the major players are more seriously involved and the Tour is properly under way, it is unlikely he will remain there.

Yet say he did, and this was Ryder Cup year. If it was just about the Tour, Lipsky could be a candidate to play against his own country at Whistling Straits in 2020. He isn't. He couldn't be. Nor could Xander Schauffele, the American who finished fourth in the European rankings in 2018.

Patrick Reed, the American who seems to get most from the Ryder Cup, was Europe's second-ranked golfer last year. One imagines he wouldn't be greatly open to changing allegiance, either.

As far as the Ryder Cup goes, it's not where you're at, it's where you're from, and McIlroy is an Ulsterman who chooses to play, and live, in America because that is where the best, most lucrative and most challenging action is. Does that leave him disconnected from the European team? Not at all.

McIlroy is often discussed as a huge influence, as is Sergio Garcia, and both men decided long ago that the greatest test of their talents could be found in America.

Anyway, it is not as if the European Tour is tied to the continent, either. A look at the 2019 schedule, which begins on January 16, finds it actively avoids Europe until May 9 and before that can be found in Abu Dhabi, Dubai, Saudi Arabia, Australia, Mexico, Muscat, Qatar, Kenya, Malaysia, the United States, India, Morocco and China. It goes where the money is, yet gets huffy if Europe's golfers do the same.

At the World Cup last summer, two countries, Sweden and Senegal, did not have a single player in their squad from the domestic league. Sweden won Germany's group and reached the quarter-finals.

Croatia, with just two players from their domestic competition — Dominik Livakovic, the unused third-choice goalkeeper, and midfielder Filip Bradaric, who featured as a substitute for 25 minutes against Iceland — did even better, making the final.

Nobody considered the other 21 players unsupportive of their nation or unpatriotic. Indeed, Croats appear rather proud of Luka Modric, the World Footballer of the Year, an accolade he certainly would not have won had he remained with his original club, Dinamo Zagreb.

Modric left for Tottenham in 2008, and then Real Madrid, to test himself against the world's best, and it is the same for McIlroy. America's Tour is the strongest and most competitive.

The United States have five players in the world's top six, and 13 in the top 20. Why should McIlroy be penalised for wanting to go up against them, in the country that also boasts three of golf's four majors?

Everyone recognises the significance of the PGA Tour. Between 1993 and 1999, Colin Montgomerie won the European Tour seven straight seasons — but the fact he could not win so much as a tournament on the American circuit, until competing as a senior, will always count against him in the pantheon of golf's greats.

Montgomerie was a fine player, but his legacy is devalued by choosing not to compete against Tiger Woods and the best of his day, week in, week out. That was never going to be true of McIlroy, and with four major wins already to his name, plus 10 on the PGA Tour, and seven in Europe, he may yet return to the pinnacle.

The criticism is unfair. McIlroy has already paid his dues in European golf. He has won in England, Ireland and Switzerland, plus points east. He has been the European Tour's poster boy and, since 2015, the financial saviour of the Irish Open, which his foundation has sponsored in conjunction with Dubai Duty Free.

Now, for the first half of 2019 at least, he has made his intentions clear. 'I want to play against the strongest fields,' he announced, 'to continue to contend in the majors and to continue my journey back towards the top of the game.'

To that end, so far, he has only signed up for the Scottish Open and the European Masters — two short of the number of tournaments needed for European Tour membership.

Keith Pelley, the chief executive, is trying to persuade him to commit further and space in the calendar remains. McIlroy has spoken of considering his options again in August, so may acquiesce. If he does not, however, does this make him any less European?

There is no question, as yet, that McIlroy will not commit to Europe's Ryder Cup effort. All he has rejected at this juncture is its business plan, and its value to a golfer of his immense calibre.

Padraig Harrington, Europe's Ryder Cup captain, remains convinced McIlroy will do what is required to make the Ryder Cup team when the time comes and there is no reason to doubt him. McIlroy is equally insistent.

'Everyone has to look out for themselves,' he added. 'I'm looking out for me.' As this very European tour heads once again to Abu Dhabi next week, most would surely understand.

Arnie is over-rated but don't sell now

Even if the money for Marko Arnautovic was right at £36million, the timing for West Ham is all wrong. Selling the fans' favourite player in January, with the club three points off what might be a European place come the end of the season, is a guaranteed way to sour the mood at the London Stadium.

Arnautovic is over-rated, mostly by Arnautovic. He thinks he is a Champions League player, but his numbers do not back that up.

There are 17 players ahead of him in the Premier League scorers' table this season, including three at Liverpool, two at Manchester City, Tottenham, Manchester United and Everton — and even one, Felipe Anderson, at West Ham.

Mark Hughes's staff at Stoke rated Arnautovic as one great game in three and while he has undoubtedly improved since then, he can still deteriorate into petulance, fading into anonymity save an explosion of arm-waving at the perceived failings of his team-mates. At his best, he can be the difference. At his worst, he is high-maintenance, anonymous and disruptive.

Every time he goes on a scoring run, there are rumours he wants to leave. Now he wants West Ham to sell him to an unnamed Chinese entity at a time that would be ruinous to their season — and to the board's fragile relationship with the fans.

Without doubt, the presence of Arnautovic, along with the investment in Anderson and others, and the emergence of Declan Rice, has eased tensions at the club. West Ham are playing good football and improving under Manuel Pellegrini, and when this happens, the locals are no longer greatly enraged by separation from their favourite pie and mash shop.

The London Stadium, like any other football ground, turns on results. And there is no better way to bring the bad vibes back than to start losing games having sold the best striker to China.

Had the Arnautovic deal been offered in the summer, that would be different. A January sale, however, leaves little room for manoeuvre. West Ham's board might favour Callum Wilson but there is minimal chance of extracting him from Bournemouth in January with Eddie Howe's team in freefall.

It all smacks too familiarly of the Dimitri Payet fiasco in 2017 when West Ham insisted there would be no sale to Marseille only to cave in at the last, and let him leave for a cut price £25m. Payet has created more chances than any other player in a major European league again this season. He is also wanted in China, and if he leaves, Marseille are expecting to make a profit on a midfielder who will be 32 in March.

No wonder Arnautovic's advisers are refusing to take no for an answer.

West Ham have rejected the bid for Arnautovic, but his brother Danijel still insists he wants out, talking of West Ham paying 'peanuts' for his services — it was £20m, a club record, rising to £25m with add-ons — and of the player fulfilling West Ham's desire to keep them in the Premier League.

Actually, he was signed in July 2017 in the hope that he could help them push for Europe. Perhaps by scoring more than 11 league goals last season.

No doubt West Ham's directors fear another Payet saga. They should be warned against capitulation a second time, though. Not just for what it would do to the team, or for the message it would send to the rest of the Premier League regarding Rice, but for its impact on a tender truce. Peace has broken out in Stratford, albeit uneasily. Allow it to reign until the summer, at least.

City are incredible but aren't invincible

Manchester City 9 Burton Albion 0 was not a result that was good for football, but nor is it a portent.

There will always be the odd mismatch in cup competition, but Premier League teams who rest players are often eliminated by spirited inferiors: it happened to Fulham and Leicester only last Sunday.

And a year ago, do not forget, the Manchester City team who would go on to be the most emphatic champions of all time, could only defeat Bristol City in a League Cup semi-final 5-3 on aggregate, before being eliminated from the FA Cup by Wigan.

Indeed, in home and away meetings last season, only Liverpool in the Champions League and Manchester United in the league scored more against Pep Guardiola's side than humble Bristol City.

From any angle, Kepa failed

VAR takes long enough without the official having to consider every conceivable camera angle, including those provided by the affected club.

Surely, Harry Kane’s goal for Tottenham against Chelsea comes under the umbrella of benefit of the doubt to the attacking side. If a linesman could truly judge such a fine margin in real time accurately, he is wasted in football, and should be in the space programme.

And, from Chelsea’s point of view, isn’t all this a way of avoiding admitting that the world’s most expensive goalkeeper, Kepa Arrizabalaga, made a reckless, woeful, decision and cost his team the game?

Three suits, but Ramsey doesn't fit

Edu is in the frame to be Arsenal’s new director of football, begging the question: just how many bosses do they need?

There is Raul Sanllehi, head of football, Sven Mislintat, head of recruitment, plus Unai Emery, the manager. That’s three chiefs and counting, and yet none of them fancied Aaron Ramsey, a player a club with ambitions to win the Champions League, Juventus, have snapped up on a five-year free transfer deal starting next season.

It now takes three men to lose the type of player Arsene Wenger could misplace all on his own.

item.title: UK Athletics chairman Richard Bowker under increasing pressure as calls for an emergency general meeting to vote on his future gains high level support
item.description: EXCLUSIVE BY MATT LAWTON: The push for an emergency general meeting to vote on the future of UK Athletics chairman Richard Bowker is understood to have gained high level support.
item.content:encoded:
The push for an emergency general meeting to vote on the future of UK Athletics chairman Richard Bowker is understood to have gained high level support in the form of senior coaches representative Toni Minichiello and athlete representative Hannah England.

As Sportsmail has already revealed, Bowker is facing calls to stand down from the 12-strong UK Athletics Members Council amid a hugely damaging political crisis at the governing body.

Last month the Members Council rejected a proposal by the UKA board to essentially divide the role of the chairman into two, with Sarah Rowell dealing with domestic issues as vice-chair while Bowker focused more on international duties.

It was seen as a solution to easing the conflict between Bowker and the home nations, with the situation so bad Scottish Athletics are seeking independence.

But the Members Council have already called for Bowker to be removed and after taking legal advice to make sure they were compliant with the UK companies act, they finally submitted a letter this week requesting the EGM to vote on the UKA chairman's future.

In the letter, this newspaper has been told, support extends on the Members Council to both Minichiello and former world silver medallist England, with the majority of the council supporting the move having already issued a vote of no confidence in Bowker.

As Sportsmail first revealed, Bowker has incensed the representatives of the home nations with his plan to streamline UK Athletics, not least by absorbing England Athletics into UKA at their same Birmingham headquarters.

England Athletics have stated they have no intention of merging and right now the political crisis is not only delaying the search for a new chief executive, after Niels De Vos suddenly resigned in September, but starting to incur major legal costs for UKA.

item.title: Manolo Gabbiadini set to leave Southampton and rejoin Sampdoria in permanent £11.7million switch
item.description: Manolo Gabbiadini is poised to join Sampdoria from Southampton in a permanent deal worth £11.7million. Gabbiadini is expected to travel to his native Italy on Thursday to complete the move.
item.content:encoded:
Manolo Gabbiadini is poised to join Sampdoria from Southampton in a permanent deal worth £11.7million.

Gabbiadini is expected to travel to his native Italy on Thursday in order to complete the transfer back to one of his former clubs.

He has been frozen out since Ralph Hasenhuttl replaced Mark Hughes as manager of the Saints.

Gabbiadini, 27, was signed from Napoli for £14m two years ago and made a prolific start to his career in the Premier League.

He will leave St Mary's having managed 12 goals in 55 games - including just one in 10 games this season.

The 11-cap Italy international signed for Sampdoria in 2013, registering 19 goals in 55 appearances before leaving for Napoli two years later.

item.title: Chelsea may report Bayern Munich to FIFA for tapping up teenage wonderkid Callum Hudson-Odoi
item.description: Chelsea will report Bayern Munich to FIFA if they find evidence of an illegal approach by the Bundesliga club to Hudson-Odoi, his family or his representatives. Bayern have bid £35m.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea will report Bayern Munich to FIFA if they find evidence of an illegal approach by the Bundesliga club to Callum Hudson-Odoi, his family or his representatives.

Bayern have bid £35million for 18-year-old Hudson-Odoi, understood to be an initial £15m with £20m in add-ons.

'He is fast, good at dribbling, he would fit very well into our team,' said Bayern sporting director Hasan Salihamidzic on Wednesday as he addressed the media at a training camp in Qatar.

Premier League rules prohibit such public comment but Bayern have not broken any FIFA regulations unless they are found to have 'tapped up' Hudson-Odoi.

Chelsea do not want to sell but they could lose him for next to nothing when his contract expires in summer 2020.

Hudson-Odoi has been sounding out Berlin-born team-mate Antonio Rudiger.

'He asked me about Germany,' said Rudiger. 'I can advise him but at the end of the day he decides his future.

'You can see it from both sides. He can develop here but he can develop in Germany as well. And don't forget Bayern Munich are also a big club. For his future, I wish him all the best but I just wish he stays with us.'

item.title: FA plan to probe West Ham's £250k deal with USM after agency sponsored shirts for the club's women's team
item.description: MATT LAWTON - CHIEF SPORTS REPORTER: The FA plan to question West Ham United over the sponsorship of their women’s team by a leading sports management agency.
item.content:encoded:
The FA plan to question West Ham United over the sponsorship of their women’s team by a leading sports management agency.

Based on claims from within the club, Sportsmail understands the deal to have the logo for Unique Sports Management on the back of the shirts of the West Ham women’s team is the biggest of its kind in the FA Women’s Super League.

It is believed to be close to £250,000, although neither the club nor USM will confirm this — or whether the deal is just for this season or a number of seasons.

West Ham are unhappy that an arrangement which supports their women’s team — when it remains difficult to secure such levels if sponsorship in the women’s game — is being scrutinised.

Not least when all sponsorship deals in the WSL have to first be approved by the FA.

But following the report by Sportsmail earlier this week about USM’s involvement with the women’s team, Wembley officials now consider it appropriate to make further inquiries with regard to the deal.

It is likely they will want to know the circumstances in which USM were asked to sponsor the team which is run by the 19-year-old son of West Ham co-owner David Sullivan.

Jack Sullivan, his brother David and their father are known to enjoy a close personal relationship with USM boss Will Salthouse, a regular in the directors’ box at the London Stadium.

USM reportedly represent five current members of Manuel Pellegrini’s squad and, according to information published by the FA last year, were involved in five intermediary transactions with the club between February 1 2017 and January 31 2018.

A further player represented by the agency was signed by the club last summer.

But the partnership with the women’s team has caused concern among the representatives of other players at the club amid fears that it underlines what they consider to be a growing influence being enjoyed by Salthouse and a potential conflict of interest.

A West Ham spokesperson issued a statement on Wednesday night claiming that the USM deal represents just 15 per cent of total annual commercial income of the women’s team.

The statement said: ‘The West Ham United women’s team attracted strong interest at the start of the season from a wide range of high-profile brands due to the level of investment into the team at all levels, from infrastructure to signing some of the world’s best players. This investment, together with its new management team, has put the club on an upward trajectory culminating in its momentous rise into the Women’s Super League this season.

‘This has drawn high-profile media interest including a BBC documentary, all of which has contributed to the growth in the appeal of the women’s team to commercial brands.

‘The deal with USM — which represents less than 15 per cent of the total annual commercial income the women’s team has managed to secure from a range of well-known brands — includes significant high-value hospitality packages at both men’s and women’s matches. This is a commercial deal, no different in nature to any other we have with our partners at the club.’

item.title: FA reaches settlement with former England women's boss Mark Sampson over case of unfair dismissal
item.description: Former England women's manager Mark Sampson has reached a settlement with the Football Association. Sampson, 36, was sacked by the FA in September 2017.
item.content:encoded:
The FA have reached a settlement with former England women’s manager Mark Sampson after he sued for unfair dismissal following his sacking in 2017.

Sampson, who had become the subject of an investigation concerning allegations of racial discrimination made by former international Eniola Aluko, was dismissed after evidence emerged of ‘inappropriate and unacceptable’ behaviour with female players in a previous role.

Martin Glenn, the outgoing FA chief executive, alleged that Sampson had ‘breached professional boundaries’ while a coach at Bristol Academy, the role he occupied before joining the FA in December 2013.

Sampson, 36, responded by bringing an unfair dismissal case against the FA — and Wembley officials confirmed yesterday that a settlement had been reached with the case due to be heard this week.

A statement from an FA spokesperson said: ‘We can confirm that a confidential settlement has been entered into between the FA and Mark Sampson to bring the dispute around the termination of his employment to an agreed close.’

Sampson, who guided England to a bronze medal at the 2015 FIFA Women’s World Cup, is sure to consider this a victory given the damage suffered to his reputation.

At the time Sampson had a £100,000-a-year contract until 2019 to take the team to this year’s World Cup in France. Phil Neville now has that job.

After Sampson’s dismissal the FA said that, while an internal assessment of allegations against him relating to his time at Bristol had concluded that he did not pose a risk, they had been made aware of safeguarding allegations.

Glenn said he had revisited the report in 2017 and faced criticism for not being more inquisitive when he was made aware of a safeguarding issue with the senior women’s coach.

FA chairman Greg Clarke said Sampson should have been sacked ‘years ago’. By then, though, Sampson had been cleared over racism allegations made by players including Aluko.

item.title: Referee chiefs backing Michael Oliver after Tottenham's controversial VAR winner against Chelsea in Cup
item.description: The referees' bosses at the PGMO are satisfied Michael Oliver reached the correct decision over Tottenham's controversial penalty against Chelsea in the Carabao Cup semi-final.
item.content:encoded:
The referees' bosses at the PGMOL are satisfied Michael Oliver and his officials, including his video assistant Chris Kavanagh, reached the correct decision over Tottenham's controversial penalty against Chelsea in the Carabao Cup semi-final.

Maurizio Sarri was furious after losing 1-0 at Wembley to a penalty scored by Harry Kane and awarded by referee Oliver after consultation with his VAR Kavanagh.

Sarri paraded footage from Chelsea's own video analysts to support his claim that Kane was offside before he was fouled by goalkeeper Kepa Arrizabalaga.

Kavanagh would not have been able to access this precise piece of footage filmed by Chelsea's own analysis team from the gantry or the lines they digitally superimposed onto the pitch.

Instead, the VAR made his decision using replays from different angles made available by the broadcaster, which in this case was Sky.

The virtual offside lines Kavanagh used were superimposed onto the Sky footage using Hawkeye software which is trusted and was tested before the game.

Chelsea's are not verified and the ball in Sarri's still image was blurred, which experts believe means the frame was frozen a split-second too late.

This is unlikely to soothe any sense of injustice at Stamford Bridge.

item.title: 'They gave me the confidence to stay': Toby Alderweireld insists he's happy to remain at Tottenham for another year
item.description: His contract will not expire next year but, by activating this extension, Spurs have triggered a clause which means the centre-half will be allowed to leave for £27million during a set period of time.
item.content:encoded:
Toby Alderweireld insists he is happy to stay at Tottenham for another season after the club activated a one-year extension in his contract.

'I am very happy to stay another year,' said Alderweireld. 'It was in my contract and I'm happy Spurs gave me the confidence to stay another year.'

His contract will not expire next year but, by activating this extension, Spurs have triggered a clause which means the centre half will be allowed to leave for £27million during a set period of time in the summer.

'I am only focused on things on the pitch,' said Alderweireld after Tottenham beat Chelsea in the first leg of the Carabao Cup semi-final.

'People can see every time I play that I give 100 per cent for this club. This is what I keep doing every time I play.

'This is my fourth season and I'm very happy. I'm doing everything to help the team.'

item.title: Desperate for a striker, N'Golo Kante compromised for Jorginho and no Plan B… why Maurizio Sarri and Chelsea are searching for answers amid sub-par 'Sarriball'
item.description: MATT BARLOW: Losing twice to Spurs inside seven weeks at Wembley is no Chelsea fan's idea of a having a good time and the manager is searching for answers.
item.content:encoded:
Maurizio Sarri arrived at Chelsea promising fun and after a season of Antonio Conte's thunderous moods it was a message well received.

Eden Hazard perked up immediately as the campaign opened with an unbeaten run of 18 games in all competitions and there was even a time, albeit brief, when it seemed he might solve the Alvaro Morata puzzle.

There was lots to like about Sarriball and its eccentric creator, lost in his own world of tactical analysis, tobacco and superstition.

Then came the humbling at the hands of Tottenham in November and the impetus has faded, goals have dried up and the arm of Sarri's fun-o-meter swung back from the image of happy Hazard to the glum face of Morata.

Not a lot is wrong. Chelsea are tight at the back and can dominate in midfield, but at the very top not a lot needs to be wrong and losing twice to Spurs inside seven weeks at Wembley is no Chelsea fan's idea of a having a good time and the manager is searching for answers.

LACK OF A STRIKER

This time last year Conte, the manager who ostracised Diego Costa, was in a flap about signing a centre forward, having quickly decided Morata, the £68million then-record signing, was not the answer.

Eventually, Olivier Giroud arrived but 12 months on and Sarri wants a new man up front. How he must look at Tottenham and long for Harry Kane when his own team cannot convert comfortable possession into goal threat.

Hazard through the centre denies Chelsea their best player: Hazard the wide attacker, who can score and create from the spaces he finds on the left.

Willian and Pedro, even when fit and fresh, cannot do what Hazard does in the wide areas. Callum Hudson-Odoi has caught the eye but what's the point of an old fashioned winger whipping crosses into the box if there's no-one with a goal scorer's instinct on the end?

With Hazard up front, dropping short for the ball, there is no threat in behind which, arguably, Chelsea have lacked since Costa's exit.

Conte craved a technical centre forward, who could hold up the ball, bring others into play and still offer aerial presence and weigh in with goals. So does Sarri.

Conte wanted Gonzalo Higuain. So does Sarri. Higuain is still very expensive and now 31. The deal makes little business sense.

THE MIDFIELD CONUNDRUM

NGolo Kante is a midfielder made for English football. Quick with endless stamina, a low centre of gravity and an ability to read the game.

He can cover the miles and prey on mistakes forced by the hustle and bustle. He wins the ball and moves it quickly; a turnover specialist.

He was the secret behind the Leicester miracle, helped Chelsea to the title and France to the World Cup.

He has signed a new five-year contract, thought to be worth £290,000 a week and yet he does not fit smoothly into Sarri's three-man midfield.

It's hard to believe no-one saw this one coming. Jorginho is so crucial to Sarriball that it was the one summer signing he demanded before taking the job.

In this tactical system, he is the pivotal player, orchestrating the tempo and rhythm on the ball.

Kante is not a holding midfielder, he cannot play this position. He is a ball-winning midfielder and needs licence to run.

Conte soon realised he was wasted, sitting in front of the centre-halves when he switched from 4-2-3-1 to 3-4-3, the key moment in 2016-17.

Chelsea fixtures

Premier League unless stated

Saturday Newcastle (H)

January 19 Arsenal (A)

January 24 Tottenham (H) Carabao Cup semi-final, second leg

January 26/27 Sheffield Wednesday or Luton (H) FA Cup fourth round

January 30 Bournemouth (A)

February 2 Huddersfield (H)

He can operate perfectly well on the right side of Sarri's midfield trio and sometimes even look good but this role does not maximise his unique talents.

No longer does everyone leave every Chelsea game thinking: Wow, Kante…

With Hazard through the centre and Kante on the right, they are without their two best players. Jorginho, meanwhile, has become too easy to neutralise and has not been able to justify this decision to compromise Kante.

To get the best from Kante, the manager would have to abandon the system to which he is wed. If Chelsea truly believed in Sarriball they would have sold him in the summer to Paris Saint-Germain and used the millions to buy players who fit the system.

TURN UP THE PACE

During the early part of the season when results were going well, it was the tempo which concerned Sarri. He wanted the ball moving more quickly. He demanded one-touch and two-touch football and movement from his team.

Chelsea have high-quality players. They soon picked it up. But opponents have reacted to combat the threat.

They sit back, congest key areas, crowd Sarri's team and then try to damage them on the counter-attack.

Leicester and Wolves, quick on the break, beat them. Tottenham's penalty at Wembley came from a long ball over the top.

Losing Pedro to injury didn't help. Pedro is fast and direct and his powers may be fading but he still offers Sarri something his other strikers don't.

Also, Chelsea do not have the speed at full back when others do. Cesar Azpilicueta was ideal for Conte's back three. Marcos Alonso, a terrific wing-back. Neither fit quite so perfectly into Sarri's plans.

At the same time, fatigue is setting in, testing Sarri's desire to operate with a small core of first-team players, resisting any major squad rotation, even in the early stages of the Europa League and the Carabao Cup.

The development stages of a successful foreign coach arriving in the Premier League often follows a similar theme.

They will arrive and demand more running and intensity, then realise all this high-intensity running around in the world's most competitive league and its demanding fixture fixtures is tiring, and then complain about the gruelling schedule and demand more players.

NO PLAN B

Perhaps most noticeable in the goalless draw against Southampton when Ralph Hasenhuttl came to Stamford Bridge with a plan to bore Chelsea into submission.

Sarri's team had 72 per cent of possession and 17 shots but only six on target. The numbers were similar at Spurs in the Carabao Cup. Only Hazard's individuality lifted Chelsea above the ordinary at Watford on Boxing Day.

As more teams - especially those unwilling to go toe-to-toe at football - adopted this tactical plan, scoring has become a problem for Chelsea.

Sarri said he was satisfied up to the last 20 metres of the pitch against Saints but the last 20 metres is the important bit.

Chelsea have failed to find the net in three of their last six games and the manager is behaving as if he thinks he does not have the solution inside his squad.

Still, he keeps plugging away with his way of playing.

Liverpool finished against Manchester City with Virgil van Dijk at centre-forward. When all else fails, go long to the biggest man you have. When you're crowded out, the most obvious alternatives are set-pieces and aerial attack.

But Sarri seems so devoted to his system he has shown no hint of a willingness to change.

Maybe a new centre forward would help. Maybe Higuain can provide the technical presence and score enough goals to make a difference. Maybe it would offer Hazard a little more freedom. Maybe it would lift the manager.

Sarriball, however, is a collective philosophy. Maybe it will need more than a new centre forward before it is remodelled successfully for the Premier League.

item.title: Tottenham 1-0 Chelsea: Harry Kane's VAR-assisted penalty gives Spurs first-leg advantage in Carabao Cup semi-final
item.description: MATT BARLOW AT WEMBLEY: Tottenham might be cooling on the Wembley experience but the prospect of a return in a cup final ought to be enough to rekindle the glow.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham might be cooling on the whole Wembley experience but the prospect of a return in a cup final ought to be enough to rekindle the glow.

There is still work to do at Stamford Bridge if Mauricio Pochettino is to lead his team out in the Carabao Cup final on February 24.

Chelsea responded once behind and it is well within their powers of recovery to turn it around when these London rivals meet again in a fortnight, in a competition where away goals do not count.

MATCH FACTS, PLAYER RATINGS AND MATCH ZONE

Tottenham (4-1-3-1): Gazzaniga 7, Trippier 6.5, Alderweireld 7, Sanchez 6.5, Rose 6, Winks 7 (Skipp 89min), Sissoko 6, Eriksen 6.5 (Llorente 90+1), Alli 6.5, Kane 7.5, Son 6 (Lamela 79)

Subs not used: Walker-Peters, Davies, Lloris, Foyth

Goalscorers: Kane pen 27

Booked: Winks, Sanchez, Lamela

Manager: Mauricio Pochettino 6.5

Chelsea (4-3-3): Kepa 6, Azpilicueta 6, Rudiger 7, Christensen 6.5, Alonso 6, Kante 7, Jorginho 6, Barkley 6.5 (Kovacic 75, 6), Willian 6 (Pedro 63, 6), Hazard 7, Hudson-Odoi 7 (Giroud 79)

Subs not used: Caballero, Zappacosta, Ampadu, Luiz

Booked: Kepa

Manager: Maurizio Sarri 6

Referee: Michael Oliver 7

Man of the Match: Harry Kane

Ratings by Sami Mokbel

The advantage, however, belongs to Spurs at the half way stage, courtesy of a first-half penalty scored by Harry Kane and awarded with the help of the video assistant referee.

This time there was no malfunction with the new technology as the officials reached the right decision, ruling out offside and confirming the foul inside a couple of minutes.

Kane stepped forward to score in a sixth successive appearance. Very rarely does he malfunction these days.

Pochettino will have little opportunity to dwell on the result as he turns his attention to facing a rejuvenated Manchester United but he will be proud of the way his team dug in to resist Chelsea's fight back in the second half.

At times, it was not pretty. Certainly not the fluent attacking style Tottenham are capable of producing but it was precisely the sort of rugged, winning football their Argentine manager admires and wants to see more often.

He called for naughtiness on the eve of the game. Perhaps it put his players in the right frame of mind. There were scuffles, although nothing quite as unruly as the infamous 'Battle of the Bridge' in 2016.

Chelsea did not buckle either, as they had in the Premier League in November and deserved an equaliser.

Twice Maurizio Sarri's side struck the frame of the goal in the closing stages of the first half and they dominated for long spells in control after the interval.

They had 17 efforts at goal, according to the statistical wizards, with only five on target and found Paulo Gazzaniga still in terrific form, as he has been throughout this competition.

Sarri can be encouraged by aspects of the second half, the way they moved the ball and stretched Spurs and yet will have been hugely frustrated not to find the net, which will intensify his determination to land a new striker in the transfer market.

What would he give for a centre forward like Kane?

There was no sign of Alvaro Morata, scorer of both goals in the win in the FA Cup third round tie on Saturday, and absent with a slight hamstring strain on a day when Sevilla and Valencia explored the idea of signing the Spain striker on loan.

Eden Hazard was back in the centre forward role he doesn't always enjoy and Callum Hudson-Odoi's dazzling second-half display against Nottingham Forest in the FA Cup was enough to earn him another start on a day when Bayern Munich increased their offer to £35million.

Hudson-Odoi forced Gazzaniga into an early save in a breathless opening and Kane's overhead kick did not extend Kepa Arrizabalaga.

Pochettino deployed a midfield diamond, a ploy which worked so well in November when Dele Alli smothered Jorginho, but there were no complicated tactics behind the move leading to the only goal.

Toby Alderweireld launched a long, straight and simple ball from central defence into an inside left channel and Kane was first onto it.

With a burst of pace and a toe poke, he nudged it past Arrizabalaga who careered from his goal and with his momentum sent the Spurs striker cartwheeling.

Referee Michael Oliver called for assistance from the VAR. Replays showed the foul was clear but the offside call was tight.

Chelsea players protested as Wembley held its breath until eventually Oliver received the information he needed, pointed to the spot and showed a yellow card to the goalkeeper.

Kane kept his nerve and whipped the penalty kick into the corner of the net.

It was his 160th Tottenham goal and eased him above Cliff Jones and into fourth place in the all-time list of top scorers.

Chelsea hit back. First N'Golo Kante made a darting run and turned a cross from Marcos Alonso against the foot of a post.

Then an attempted cross from Hudson-Odoi clipped Danny Rose and swerved high over Gazzaniga, who adjusted his feet and twisted in the air to produce a fabulous save, turning the ball against the same post with his fingertips.

The rebound spun in front of goal and Alderweireld hoisted it clear as Hudson-Odoi held his head.

Results can hinge on the smallest margins and Spurs reached the sanctuary of half-time with their lead intact and returned with purpose.

Kane tested Arrizabalaga with a fierce drive from distance before Chelsea took control.

Hazard dropped deeper to find more of the ball and influence the game as he had not in the first half and the visitors began to stitch together patterns of possession with a little more menace.

Gazzaniga made diving saves to frustrate Hazard and Kante. Andreas Christensen, at full stretch, was unable to convert at the back post as he arrived alone to reach a corner flicked on by Ross Barkley.

Sarri sent on Pedro on the right to add pace, with Hudson-Odoi switching to the left, and Mateo Kovacic to add fresh legs in search of an equaliser.

There were enthusiastic late appeals for penalties but Tottenham survived. One clean sheet from another game at Wembley, this time with a difference.

item.title: Reading reject £450,000 offer from Wigan to sign former Manchester United defender Tyler Blackett
item.description: Wigan, recently taken over by Chinese investors, are keen to boost defensive options and replace Dan Burn, who was sold to Brighton in the summer but returned to spend the first half of the season on loan.
item.content:encoded:
Reading have rejected an offer of £450,000 from Wigan to sign their former Manchester United defender Tyler Blackett.

Wigan, recently taken over by Chinese investors, are keen to boost defensive options this month and replace Dan Burn, who was sold to Brighton in the summer but returned to spend the first half of the season back on loan at the DW Stadium.

They have identified Blackett who is versatile enough to operate in central defence or at left back as a top target but have now had three bids turned down by their Championship rivals.

The 24-year-old, after a difficult start to his career away from Old Trafford, has matured into a strong and athletic defender who has been in impressive form this season.

Middlesbrough and Stoke have also shown interest.

Reading are next to bottom of the Championship, six points behind Wigan with only 20 points from 26 games with new manager Jose Gomes at the helm.

Gomes has already started a clear out, with midfielder Pelle Clement released to link up with former Royals boss Jaap Stam at FC Zwolle in Holland's Eredivisie.

Dave Edwards has left the Madejski Stadium for Shrewsbury and young striker Ben House has joined Swindon on loan.

Reading have signed midfielder Ovie Ejaria on loan from Liverpool until the end of the season.

item.title: Padraig Harrington aims dig at Nick Faldo, defends Rory McIlroy and eyes wildcard cut as he's named Ryder Cup captain for 2020
item.description: The three-time major winner succeeds Thomas Bjorn, as Europe bid to defend the trophy. He was announced as captain at a press conference at the European Tour's Wentworth headquarters.
item.content:encoded:
Europe’s new Ryder Cup captain Padraig Harrington said more on his first day yesterday than many of his predecessors disclosed in six months.

If this is what he is dishing up on a ceremonial day filled usually with rah-rah cliches, the next 20 months should be compelling.

It was intriguing enough during the formal announcement when he became the first captain not to resort to blandishments such as ‘it’s an honour’, but admitted to a sense of ‘trepidation’ and feeling ‘daunted’ at the scale of the task.

What followed, though, was spellbinding, as one nugget followed another. For starters, he will be advocating a tweak to the qualifying system, with three wildcards instead of four.

He followed that with the revelation there will be no place for close friend Paul McGinley on his backroom team. There was a robust defence of Rory McIlroy after his controversial remarks about the European Tour being a ‘stepping stone’ to the PGA Tour, before a dig at Sir Nick Faldo’s captaincy in 2008.

As ever, each point was thoughtfully delivered, with plenty of humour, too. Asked whether there was any chance of him following in the footsteps of Thomas Bjorn and getting a tattoo done where the sun doesn’t shine, he replied: ‘I think it’s time we rear-ended that tradition, don’t you?’

Let’s start with McGinley. Such an inspirational skipper at Gleneagles in 2014, why wouldn’t you call on his wisdom as a vice-captain? ‘I will be relying on Paul, of course but not in an official capacity,’ said Harrington.

‘He doesn’t need to be coming back. I feel the job has moved on and it’s incumbent on the captain to bring players in as vice-captains who could be future captains. It’s too important a role now, and no longer a jolly, if it ever was.’

You might have thought he would get his feet under the table before tackling the qualification process but, again, he displays impeccable logic. ‘I’m having stats done to see if they back up what I feel anecdotally but I’m leaning to three picks instead of four,’ he said.

‘I find it hard to think how you would overlook the ninth player in the qualifying list, when you’ve got four picks, and my experience is that a player who finishes ninth feels more comfortable and has more belief in himself when he’s qualified rather than getting a pick.’

What about McIlroy — is it damaging to team morale when he is so disparaging about his home tour? ‘I read what Rory said but look at his actions,’ argued Harrington. ‘That man loves the Ryder Cup, and he gets so much from it that he can’t get anywhere else. He’s not 30 yet and he gets to be the leader in the team room. He gets the glory and the opportunity to be loved on the course.

‘He will be 100 per cent behind us, don’t worry about that. Yes, he’s moved to America, and his family is there. He wants to win the Masters, and so those words come out. But if you know the man behind the scenes, he’s as European as they come.’

Harrington appears such a natural fit, it comes as something of a shock to hear he wrestled long and hard before taking on the captaincy.

‘I can see it’s a natural progression after being a player on six occasions and a vice-captain three times, but it’s not something I’ve taken on lightly,’ said the 47-year-old Irishman.

‘Just because it might seem to be my time doesn’t mean I didn’t think deeply about it. There’s a certain trepidation because I really want to leave the Ryder Cup and the European Tour in a better place.

‘But I know as captain you’re putting it on the line and you’re great if you win or it’s your fault if you lose. It’s exciting but also daunting thinking I’m going to have to find an edge if we’re to beat a very strong American team on home soil.’

Underlining the scale of the task he has taken on in defending the trophy at Whistling Straits in Wisconsin next year, only once in the last 15 years has the away team won — and that needed a miracle at Medinah. To prepare, Harrington will call on the counsel of every captain from the last 20 years. Well, all but one.

‘Eight put their heart and soul into the job, so they will certainly be a help, while one did it half-heartedly, and that didn’t end so good,’ said Harrington.

Just in case anyone had doubts as to the identity of the miscreant, Harrington added: ‘It shows that just because you’re a successful player, it doesn’t mean you’ll be a great captain.’

It promises to be a revelatory 20 months, doesn’t it?

item.title: Chelsea make Cesc Fabregas wait to complete Monaco move as they search for midfield replacement with Nicolo Barella and Leandro Paredes targeted
item.description: The Spanish midfielder was in tears as he made a lap of honour to applaud the fans after the FA Cup third round win over Nottingham Forest, as he prepares to move to Monaco.
item.content:encoded:
Cesc Fabregas is still a Chelsea player despite his emotional goodbye on Saturday, as the club want to sign a replacement before letting him leave.

The Spanish midfielder was in tears as he made a lap of honour to applaud the fans after the FA Cup third round win over Nottingham Forest, as he prepares to move to Monaco.

A contract has already been agreed between Fabregas and the Ligue 1 club, however he has returned to training at Cobham as his move is delayed.

Chelsea are hoping to conclude a deal for either Cagliari's Nicolo Barella or Leandro Paredes of Zenit Saint Petersburg before the end of the week - and will not let Fabregas go before then.

Blues manager Maurizio Sarri has told his club they must sign a replacement for Fabregas this month.

Fabregas, who won two Premier League titles with Chelsea, has agreed a three-and-half year deal at Monaco, however a free transfer deal in the summer is also in place should no replacement be signed this month.

According to L'Equipe, Fabregas has already had a photo shoot at Monaco for his unveiling by the club, and a medical was penciled in for Monday until Chelsea delayed the transfer.

Allowing Fabregas to join Monaco immediately - even on a free - would save Chelsea around £10million in wages and bonuses, however any quality replacement would not come cheap.

The Blues are said to be put off by Cagliari's £45m valuation of Barella, 21, who has been capped four times by his native Italy.

Cagliari's president has said he won't sell in January, however might change his mind if Chelsea match the asking price. Inter Milan and Napoli are also interested, with Napoli identifying him as a replacement for midfielder Alan, wanted by PSG.

Zenit would also command a tidy sum for Paredes, 24, having signed him for £20m in 2017. Paredes joined Empoli on loan from Roma as Sarri left for Napoli, meaning the Chelsea manager is very much a fan of the Argentine.

Fabregas, 31, has made just one Premier League start this season, and is unlikely to feature for Chelsea again with his future clearly away from Stamford Bridge.

Sarri said on Monday: 'In my opinion, he needs to go. You know very well the situation. He has an offer for two years. I don't want a very important player as Cesc unhappy.'

item.title: ‘Fans need to support the players and nothing else': Mauricio Pochettino and Maurizio Sarri call on Chelsea and Tottenham fans to stop using offensive terms before Carabao Cup semi-final
item.description: A semi-final which promises to deliver the best of London football on the pitch has both clubs fearing what they might hear from the Wembley stands.
item.content:encoded:
A semi-final which promises to deliver the best of London football on the pitch has both clubs fearing what they might hear from the Wembley stands.

Almost 5,000 Chelsea fans will be accompanied by Stamford Bridge stewards, and security will be tight for Tuesday night's Carabao Cup tie, the first derby against Tottenham since anti-Semitic chants resurfaced last month at a Europa League tie in Hungary.

These old songs, which use the Y-word to refer to Spurs fans, prompted UEFA to open an investigation and sparked an angry reaction from Roman Abramovich. The same songs were heard briefly in the away end at Watford on Boxing Day.

Chelsea owner Abramovich is Jewish and is determined to drive this terminology out of the club's fanbase. But some fans at Tottenham, a club with a Jewish heritage, self-identify with it.

Last week, the World Jewish Congress and the Board of Deputies of British Jews called on Spurs to 'take a stand' against its own fans who insist on calling themselves 'Yid Army' and 'Yidders'.

These sentiments were echoed on Monday, by the Jewish Leadership Council, the Community Security Trust and Action Against Discrimination.

Tottenham, however, insist the words are not used by their fans 'with any deliberate intent to cause offence' and are refusing to reassess their stance without 'a total clampdown on unacceptable anti-Semitism'.

After Budapest, Chelsea chairman Bruce Buck addressed supporters as they arrived at the turnstiles for the next fixture in Brighton, a game where one away fan was later found guilty of homophobic abuse and banned from football for three years.

With this in mind, complaints were filed to anti-discrimination campaigners Kick It Out by home fans when Nottingham Forest fans belted out a couple of noisy choruses of 'Chelsea rent boys' on Saturday. These complaints have been passed to the FA.

That football's song-book is under scrutiny is no bad thing, although in Scotland, where rivalries are often split on religious grounds, the authorities were forced to accept defeat when they tried to impose rules on songs.

Chelsea manager Maurizio Sarri said: 'We need the support of our fans for us and not against the opponents.'

Spurs boss Mauricio Pochettino added: 'Fans need to support the players and nothing else. They need to create a good atmosphere and not think about the emotion of hating each other.'

item.title: 'I'd like to ask Wenger if it was worth it': Mauricio Pochettino likens his Spurs situation job to Arsene's 'unfair' final seasons at Arsenal
item.description: MATT BARLOW: The parallels for Mauricio Pochettino are perhaps a little too clear for comfort: a north London club with heritage, a young team playing adventurous football.
item.content:encoded:
The parallels for Mauricio Pochettino are perhaps a little too clear for comfort: a north London club with a rich heritage, a young team playing adventurous football and a fabulous but very expensive new stadium to finance.

His Tottenham are rapidly adopting all the hallmarks of post-Emirates Arsenal and he knows precisely how an era of austerity ended for Arsene Wenger.

'After all that Arsene Wenger gave for Arsenal, to finish the way it finished was a little bit unfair,' said Pochettino. 'He deserves amazing recognition for his work.

'My only hope if I have the opportunity to talk with him is to ask if it was worth it. I don't know what he would say. I would like to ask.'

Wenger left Arsenal in May after 22 years. His first decade was one of unprecedented success. Then came a decade struggling to compete as the new wealth of Chelsea and Manchester City took hold.

Spurs have skipped the unprecedented success and arrived at half-time.

'It's true we work and we know the reality,' said Pochettino. 'I hope to be here for 20 years and decide to leave or finish my career here. But I don't know because I need to ask him one day if he was happy in the way he finished.

'From my point of view it was so unfair how the people treated him and talked, but we will see.'

Tottenham have not signed a new player since Lucas Moura arrived from Paris Saint-Germain almost a year ago.

The manager does not expect anyone in this month and yet, midway through his fifth season at the club, he is often told it is time to deliver trophies.

Pochettino's team are closing in on the Carabao Cup final, having beaten Arsenal in the last round.

Manchester City await in the final unless Burton Albion of League One can produce one of the greatest cup upsets of all time. On Tuesday night, Spurs face the first leg of a semi-final against Chelsea, more big-spending rivals who know how it feels at the sharp end of football's spectrum of expectation.

'I want to win the Premier League,' said Pochettino. 'It's our own pressure, our stress that we try to win. Some clubs create a different pressure. For some clubs it's only about the winning. If they sign a manager it's about winning titles, winning the Premier League or the top four.

'For us when we arrived at Tottenham it was completely different. The objective was different. Now, after five years the club is on another level but the way we operate hasn't changed.

'That is the point when people talk about winning titles. It is one thing to reduce the gap with the top four. But if we want to win titles, if we want to be real contenders, we need to operate in a different way.'

Pochettino summoned Pep Guardiola's three goalkeepers in three years at Manchester City as an example to illustrate his point.

'Joe Hart was the keeper but Guardiola says he needs a keeper to play with their feet. Who is the best? Claudio Bravo. After one year, Ederson. With money, that is how you build a team.

'If you arrive at Southampton and you want to play from the back, you need to improve your players because you cannot go to the market and buy the best keeper. That's the difference between a team who are building to win — like Chelsea, Arsenal, City, Liverpool, United — and us.

'But when people put us in the same level with expectation and everything. That is so unfair.'

The undercurrent to this brooding sense of injustice is the gathering interest in Pochettino from wealthy suitors. Both Manchester United and Real Madrid can offer the riches to build him a team which could quickly compete in a way Tottenham cannot.

Or he can stay loyal to chairman Daniel Levy at Spurs, where he has a four more years on a contract worth £8.5million a year, a team committed to his project and less pressure to bring home the silver at the end of the season.

'I am so focused here,' said Pochettino. 'I want to help the club achieve what the club want to be. We are helping the club to finish all the facilities and maybe we can win in that way. It would be fantastic.

'I am so happy to be here. I am so happy to work in that pressure. Why not? If I arrive at Tottenham and Daniel says you have £300m to spend, it is my responsibility to win.

'If I was to spend £300m and then say the project is to build step-by-step and be in the top four or maybe win something. Come on, that's not normal.

'But it's not only me. It is about decisions from the club. Sometimes you need to split because the club believe they need another type of management, not because you are good or not good, it sometimes happens.

'At the moment I think they are happy with me.'

item.title: West Ham face questions over 'conflict of interest' as sports management agency become shirt sponsors of the club's Women's Super League team
item.description: EXCLUSIVE BY MATT LAWTON: West Ham left themselves open to accusations of conflict of interest after sports management agency became shirt sponsor of their women’s team.
item.content:encoded:
West Ham have left themselves open to accusations of a conflict of interest after allowing a leading sports management agency to become the shirt sponsor of their Women's Super League team.

Unique Sports Management appear to have five members of Manuel Pellegrini's first-team squad as clients and, according to information published by the FA last year, were involved in five transactions with the club between February 1, 2017, and January 31, 2018.

A further player represented by the agency was signed by the club last summer.

The partnership with the women's team has raised fears among agents of other players at the club over what they consider to be the growing influence of USM boss Will Salthouse.

A regular in the directors' box at the London Stadium, Salthouse has a strong relationship with co-chairman David Sullivan as well as his sons, David Jnr and Jack.

The self-styled 'youngest boss in British women's football' and a central figure in a BBC documentary series following the West Ham women's team, Jack, 19, is the managing director and appears to be behind the decision to have USM as a second sponsor on the shirts of a team lying sixth in the Women's Super League.

Two agents admitted to Sportsmail that the deal makes them nervous.

One of the agents claimed it was a conflict of interest, adding: 'It just feels a bit too cosy.'

In November, Sportsmail revealed Salthouse received payments totalling £10,000 from a bookmaker — in the form of free bets — after introducing them to his players at Cheltenham racecourse.

The Sporting Chance Clinic, which was set up to support players with problems such as gambling addictions, described the agent's willingness to receive financial reward from a bookie as 'appalling'.

They said it raised concerns about a 'poor attitude to player care'.

Salthouse indicated through his lawyers that everyone who attended Cheltenham was aware of the payments.

West Ham's main shirt sponsor is the gambling platform Betway.

West Ham declined to comment on Monday night and would not reveal how much the deal is worth.

A request to USM to reveal how much they are paying to have their logo on the women's shirts also met with no response.

USM are one of the 11 sponsors secured for the women's team. The club stressed they dealt with a variety of agents during their transfer dealings last summer.

item.title: Peerless off the tee but destructive putting leaves Rory McIlroy with major problem in bid for career Grand Slam
item.description: DEREK LAWRENSON - WORLD OF GOLF: McIlroy can hardly be blamed for attempting something new in the build-up to his next tilt at the career Grand Slam at the Masters in April.
item.content:encoded:
Plenty might have tried but Rory McIlroy can hardly be blamed for attempting something new and playing solely in America in the build-up to his next tilt at the career Grand Slam at the Masters in April.

What is more concerning is the fact the start of his new adventure in Hawaii on Sunday was marked by the resurfacing of some wearingly familiar failings that leave him with no chance of attaining his goal unless they are eradicated.

Peerless off the tee, and perfectly placed in the final group after three rounds, McIlroy could not buy a putt on Sunday to fall to joint-fourth behind American Xander Schauffele. Now, where have we heard that before?

A new destination for the Northern Irishman it might have been, but it is a destructive pattern we saw in plenty of other places last year. Given how good he used to be in that position, it is scarcely believable the 29-year-old has now not won any of the last seven tournaments where he has been in the final group on Sunday.

With a conversion rate like that, no wonder he has won only once in two years.

McIlroy has drawn plenty of heat for opting to give the Middle East a miss this month and stay in America until the three US majors are done in June, but it makes perfect sense.

QUOTE OF THE WEEK

'We're going to understand everybody's perspectives as the USGA and R&A move forward with their distance insight project, but it's hard to argue you should be changing anything right now because the sport is growing and thriving.'

Hard to argue? There are plenty in the game who would strongly beg to differ with Jay Monahan, CEO of the PGA Tour, and his view that the ball doesn't travel too far. They may include the two governing bodies he mentions, who are due to release their distance insight findings shortly. And is the game really growing and thriving? Within the gilded confines of the PGA Tour, maybe.

He might have a great record in the events in Abu Dhabi and Dubai but he has often played poorly when he has returned to the US thereafter, so why venture back and forth when all the focus is on being ready for Georgia in the spring?

Sure, he could have used more temperate language last week than describing the European Tour as a 'stepping stone,' but the day we start expecting our leading players to place loyalty over ambition is when they stop winning majors and Ryder Cups.

If Rory wins the Masters, you can guarantee he will play plenty in Europe from July onwards.

Do not criticise him because he has got his priorities the right way around.

Right now, all his energies are correctly channelled on unlocking that elusive two or three per cent of improvement that will turn him into a winner again. We can see already that so much is right about his game he will be a contender, as usual, at Augusta — but can he find the missing piece?

America, for sure, is the place to be looking.

Padraig a great fit for Europe

Ignore the fact his wrist will be in a splint when Padraig Harrington is formally announced as Europe's Ryder Cup captain at Wentworth on Tuesday. The coveted post is in safe hands.

The 47-year-old slipped on the stairs at home during the Christmas break and will not be playing again until February — but you can be sure there will be no mishaps when it comes to preparing his Europe team for the mammoth task of winning at Whistling Straits next year.

Expect interviews galore over the next 18 months, when the delightful Dubliner will exhibit plenty of charm while keeping mostly hidden the hard edge that made him such an assassin when it came to winning three majors.

I'm sorry, but they really should have changed daft bunker rule

It's my New Year resolution that this is the only one I have to make but it's only right I begin 2019 with a correction. In a Boxing Day article on the dramatic rules changes that have come into effect, in a clear act of wishful thinking, I described the daft rule of punishing someone for inadvertently brushing the sand on their backswing whilst playing from a bunker as a thing of the past. Sadly, while plenty of unfair rules have been changed, this one remains in place. I should also have made it clear that relief allowed when taking a lateral drop from a red penalty area is two club lengths, not one.

Apologies, therefore, to Grant Moir of the R&A who had talked me through the new rules. And thanks, too, to all the readers who emailed to put me right.
